{{update|date=July 2015}} [[File:Monaco depuis since 1861.png|thumb|500px|Land reclamation in Monaco since 1861]] '''Land reclamation''' is done '''in [[Monaco]]''' because land is very scarce, as the nation is comparatively tiny, at 0.78 [[Mile|mi²]] (2.02 [[Kilometer|km²]]). To solve this problem and continue economic development, for years the country has been adding to its total land area by reclaiming land from the sea.
==Geography== {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2015}} The entire district of [[Fontvieille, Monaco|Fontvieille]] was constructed on land reclaimed from the sea in the 1970s. It is the newest of the four traditional quartiers (districts) in the principality of Monaco, and one of ten Wards for modern administrative purposes. It is located in the western part of Monaco.
Land has also been added to areas of [[La Condamine]] and [[Larvotto|Larvotto/Bas Moulins]].
==History== {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2015}} [[Prince Albert II|Prince Albert's]] father, [[Rainier III]], was known as the "Builder Prince". In an attempt to further develop the economy of Monaco, he first supported the idea of [[land reclamation]]. Since it was impossible to extend into France, the only solution was to reclaim land from the sea. First, the Larvotto beach district was created in the early 1960s, then the Fontvieille industrial area, increasing the principality's surface area by approximately 20 percent. More recently, [[Port Hercules]] has been extended to welcome larger cruise ships on one side, and to provide land for a new Yacht Club on the other.
==Projects== Prince Albert II is currently planning to reclaim even more land. He intends to build into the [[Mediterranean]] to create a new area about 5 hectares (12.5 acres) in size. The new district will extend from the Fontvieille district at the western foot of the [[Rock of Monaco]], where Monaco's palace and historic centre are situated. The project will cost an estimated €11 billion. It was suspended in 2009 due to the global financial crisis and the prince's concerns regarding the marine environment. However, the project was resumed in 2010 and is expected to be completed by 2014.<ref name="independent">{{cite web|title=Monaco to reclaim land from the sea|url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/europe/monaco-to-reclaim-land-from-the-sea-1990724.html|publisher=Independent.ie|accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref>
==Issues== Monaco's coastline on the Mediterranean is already a fragile and vulnerable environment. Any further land reclamation projects threaten to disturb or damage the coastal ecosystem. Monaco's leaders have approached the prospect of further land reclamation with caution and have stated that new projects would have to meet strict environmental standards to limit damage to flora and wildlife. Due to the concerns that land reclamation could potentially damage local marine ecosystems, Prince Albert II has insisted the entire expansion be placed on stilts, like an oil rig, in order to disturb the sea floor as little as possible.<ref name="independent" />
==See also== * [[Land reclamation in Hong Kong]] * [[Land reclamation in the UAE]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{more references|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox Military Structure |name=Lisbon Naval Base
''Base Naval de Lisboa'' |location=Alfeite ([[Almada]]), [[Portugal]] |image= |caption=Lisbon Naval Base |built=1920s-1950s |materials= |used=1937 - Today |type=Naval base |controlledby=[[Portuguese Navy]] |garrison= |past_commanders=Capitão de Mar e Guerra Luis Pedro Pinto Proença Mendes |battles= }} The '''Lisbon Naval Base''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: ''Base Naval de Lisboa''), is the main installation and [[naval base|operational base]] of the [[Portuguese Navy]]. Being located at the former Royal Estate of Alfeite on the south bank of the [[Tagus river]]'s huge [[estuary]], near the city of [[Almada]], the installation is sometimes referred to as the '''Alfeite Naval Base'''.[http://www.arsenal-alfeite.pt/historia History of the Alfeite Arsenal] Most of the Portuguese [[Naval fleet]] [[warship|ships]] are based at Alfeite, as well as many of its administrative, training and support services. Within its perimeter are also located the [[Portuguese Naval School|Naval School]], the Naval Technologies School, the Alfeite Arsenal, the [[Portuguese Marine Corps|Marine corps Base]] and other Portuguese Navy units.{{fact|date=July 2014}} The Lisbon Naval Base is an administrative entity that – besides the main naval station at Alfeite – manages several other smaller naval facilities in the region.{{fact||date=July 2014}} ==History== [[Lisbon]] and the neighbor Tagus estuary has always been the largest and most important [[naval base]] of [[Portugal]], since the 12th century.{{fact||date=July 2014}} During the [[Age of Discovery]], in the 15th and 16th centuries, Lisbon and the Tagus became the major naval base in the World. It was from this base, that [[Vasco da Gama]] set out to discover the sea route to [[India]]. Until after [[World War I]], in reality there was not a single naval base, but a series of smaller bases located at various points of both banks of the Tagus.{{fact||date=July 2014}} Among others, in the early 20th century, there was the Lisbon Navy Arsenal, the [[Santa Maria de Belém|Doca de Belém]] [[submarine]] base, the [[Portuguese Naval Aviation|Bom Sucesso]] [[seaplane]] base, the [[Vila Franca de Xira]] [[destroyer]] base, the Vale do Zebro [[torpedo boat]] base, the [[Alcântara (Lisbon)|Alcântara]] Naval Barracks and the Doca da Marinha naval [[quay]]. In the late 19th century, the idea of building a new [[arsenal|naval arsenal]] at the site of the Royal Estate of Alfeite arose.{{fact||date=July 2014}} Several senior naval officers also began to advocate the idea of concentrating the several Navy facilities in Lisbon and the Tagus, at a single location near the future new arsenal. Construction of the new naval arsenal began in 1928 and was completed in 1937.{{fact||date=July 2014}} Considered one of the largest and best equipped installations of its kind, the Alfeite Arsenal started full operation in 1938. A large naval complex – known as "the city of the Navy" – was built concurrently, to accommodate most of the ships, personnel and services of the Portuguese Navy. These were successively transferred to Alfeite up until the 1950s. On 3 December 1958, the '' Intendência de Marinha do Alfeite'' {Naval Administration Headquarters at Alfeite} became the Lisbon Naval Base.{{cite book|title=Noticias de Portugal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=igVPAQAAIAAJ&q=%22%20Intend%C3%AAncia%20de%20Marinha%20do%20Alfeite%22|year=1958|page=126}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|38.6692|N|9.1503|W|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Year of establishment missing]] [[Category:Portuguese Navy]] [[Category:Naval installations]] [[Category:Geography of Lisbon]] [[Category:Military installations in Portugal]]

This is a '''list of all present [[sovereign state]]s in [[North America]] and their predecessors'''. The division between North and South America is unclear, generally viewed as lying somewhere in the [[Isthmus of Panama]], however, the [[Caribbean Islands]], [[Central America]] including the whole of [[Panama]] is considered to be part of North America as its southernmost nation. The continent was [[Colony|colonized]] by the [[European colonization of the Americas|Europeans]]: Mainly by the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spaniards]], the [[French colonization of the Americas|French]], the [[English colonization of the Americas|English]] and the [[Dutch colonization of the Americas|Dutch]]. [[United States of America]] gained its independence in [[American Revolutionary War]]; Most of nations in [[Central America]] gained [[Latin American wars of independence|independence]] in the early [[19th century]]; Canada and many other island countries in the [[Caribbean Sea]] (most of them were British colonies) gained their independence in [[20th century]]. Today, North America consists of twenty-two sovereign states with common government system being some form of [[Presidential system|presidential republic]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Sovereign state ! page.title: List of presidential trips made by Donald Trump during 2017

revision.comment: /* References */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{main|Presidency of Donald Trump}} {{Donald Trump series}} This is a '''list of presidential trips made by Donald Trump during 2017''', the first year of [[Presidency of Donald Trump|his presidency]] as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|45th]] [[President of the United States]]. This list excludes trips made within [[Washington, D.C.]], the U.S. federal capital in which the [[White House]], the official residence and principal workplace of the President, is located. Also excluded are trips to [[Camp David]], the country residence of the President. [[List of international presidential trips made by Donald Trump|International trips]] are included. The number of visits per state or territory where he traveled are: *One visit to [[Alabama]], [[Arizona]], [[Connecticut]], [[Delaware]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Indiana]], [[Iowa]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Michigan]], [[Mississippi]], [[North Carolina]], [[North Dakota]], [[Puerto Rico]], [[Tennessee]] and [[Utah]] *Two visits to [[Hawaii]], [[Missouri]], [[Nevada]], [[Ohio]], [[South Carolina]], [[West Virginia]] and [[Wisconsin]] *Three visits to [[Pennsylvania]] and [[Texas]] *Five visits to [[Maryland]] *Six visits to [[New York (state)|New York]] *Ten visits to [[New Jersey]] *Twelve visits to [[Florida]] *Thirty-one visits to [[Virginia]] {{TOC left}} {{Pres. Trump USA Travels}} {{clear}} [[File:CountriesvisitedbyPresidentDonaldTrump.png|650px|thumb|center|Map showing the countries President Donald Trump has visited during his presidency. United States showed in green. Countries visited shown in blue.]] == January == {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=70|Dates ! width=550|Details |- | {{flagicon|Virginia}} ''[[Virginia]]'' | [[Langley, Virginia|Langley]] | January 21 | President Trump visited the headquarters of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) in Langley, Virginia.{{cite news |quote=Donald Trump plans to visit CIA headquarters on Saturday on his first full day as U.S. president, as he takes command of an agency that he has harshly criticized, a transition official said on Thursday. The visit to Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in Langley, Virginia, in the Washington suburbs, has a symbolic element, since Trump had questioned the CIA's conclusion that Russia was involved in cyber hacking that interfered with the U.S. election.|title=Trump to visit CIA headquarters on Saturday: transition official|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-cia-idUSKBN15333R|accessdate=January 19, 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=January 19, 2017}}{{cite news|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/01/21/trump-to-visit-cia-headquarters-after-sharply-criticizing-the-intelligence-community/ |archive-date=April 7, 2017 |date=January 21, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407193401/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/01/21/trump-to-visit-cia-headquarters-after-sharply-criticizing-the-intelligence-community/ |title=Trump visits CIA headquarters after sharply criticizing the intelligence community |first1=Philip |last1=Rucker |first2=Greg |last2=Miller |quote=President Trump visited CIA's headquarters in Northern Virginia on Saturday afternoon, making a gesture of goodwill after he harshly criticized the intelligence community in the run-up to his inauguration. |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- | {{flagicon|Pennsylvania}} ''[[Pennsylvania]]'' | [[Philadelphia]] | January 26 | First trip using Air Force One. President Trump visited Philadelphia to address Congressional [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] leaders, regarding his agenda. Trump spoke at the Philadelphia [[Loews Hotels|Loews Hotel]]. [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK Prime Minister]] [[Theresa May]] also spoke at the event. Donald Trump returned to Washington the same day.{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Tamari|title=Trump to visit Philadelphia for GOP retreat Thursday|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/capitolinq/Trump-to-visit-Philadelphia-Thursday.html|accessdate=January 24, 2017|agency=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=January 24, 2017}} |} == February == {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=70|Dates ! width=550|Details ! width=150|Image |- | {{flagicon|Delaware}} ''[[Delaware]]'' | [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]] | February 1 | President Trump visited [[Dover Air Force Base]] for the arrival of the remains of a U.S. Navy SEAL who was killed in combat and was the first known combat death under the Trump administration.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-travels-to-delaware-to-meet-remains-u-s-commando-killed-in-yemen-raid/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202222021/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-travels-to-delaware-to-meet-remains-u-s-commando-killed-in-yemen-raid/ |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |title=Trump travels to Delaware to meet remains of U.S. commando killed in Yemen raid |date=February 1, 2017 |quote=President Trump is traveling to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware Wednesday afternoon for the arrival of the remains of an American commando killed during a raid in Yemen. |deadurl=yes |df= }} | [[File:President Trump's First 100 Days- 12 (34383318385).jpg|150px]] |- | {{flagicon|Florida}} ''[[Florida]]'' | [[Mar-a-Lago]],
[[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] | {{nowrap|February 3–6}} | President Trump traveled to the Mar-a-Lago Club, to attend the 60th annual [[American Red Cross|Red Cross]] Ball, and make other public appearances in the [[West Palm Beach, Florida|West Palm Beach]] area.{{cite news|first=Shannon|last=Donnelly|title=EXCLUSIVE: President Trump to visit Mar-a-Lago next week, sources say|url=http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/local/exclusive-president-trump-visit-mar-lago-next-week-sources-say/x0hnXdGO4FDA1Bkjm8tDVM/|accessdate=January 28, 2017|agency=[[Palm Beach Post]]|date=January 26, 2017}} On February 4 he visited [[Trump International Golf Club (West Palm Beach)|his Palm Beach golf club]].{{Cite web|url=http://postonpolitics.blog.palmbeachpost.com/2017/03/05/presidential-golf-tracker-obama-333-trump-7/|title=Presidential golf tracker: Obama 333, Trump 7(?) {{!}} Post On Politics|last=Bennett|first=George|access-date=March 27, 2017}} On his way back to D.C., President Trump stopped in Tampa at [[MacDill Air Force Base]] to meet with military commanders, receive briefings, and make remarks.{{cite news|first=David|last=Jackson|title=Trump's day: MacDill Air Force Base|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/02/06/donald-trump-macdill-air-force-base/97540970/ |accessdate=February 6, 2017|date=February 6, 2017}} | |- | {{flagicon|Florida}} ''[[Florida]]'' | Mar-a-Lago,
[[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter]] | {{nowrap|February 10–12}} | President Trump traveled to Florida to play golf with Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] and discuss [[Japan–United States relations|Japanese-American relations]].{{cite news|first=Mark|last=Bradley|title=Donald Trump set for golf outing in Jupiter with Japan's prime minister|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/sports/golf/donald-trump-set-for-golf-outing-jupiter-with-japan-prime-minister/4oi29PxtAh6gPuIGjXxxMJ/|accessdate=February 9, 2017|agency=[[Palm Beach Post]]|date=February 9, 2017}} | [[File:Shinzō Abe and Donald Trump in Palm Beach (2).jpeg|150px]] |- | {{flagicon|South Carolina}} ''[[South Carolina]]'' | [[North Charleston, South Carolina|North Charleston]] | February 17 | President Trump visited a [[Boeing]] [[Boeing South Carolina|facility in North Charleston, South Carolina]] to attend the roll-out of the first [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner#787-10|787-10 Dreamliner]] built at the facility.{{cite news|first=Schuyler|last=Kropf|title=President Trump coming to North Charleston Friday for Boeing 787-10 roll-out|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/president-trump-coming-to-north-charleston-friday-for-boeing-/article_3145bd44-f2ca-11e6-bc56-03ca8d236103.html|accessdate=February 16, 2017|agency=[[The Post and Courier]]|date=February 14, 2017}} | [[File:Boeing 787-10 rollout with President Trump (33109602676).jpg|150px]] |- | {{flagicon|Florida}} ''[[Florida]]'' | [[Melbourne, Florida|Melbourne]], Mar-a-Lago | February 17–20 | President Trump held a rally at [[Orlando Melbourne International Airport]] and stayed at the Mar-a-Lago resort for the third weekend in a row, where he announced [[H. R. {{Redirect|Haunting|other uses|The Haunting (disambiguation){{!}}The Haunting}} {{unreliable sources|date=December 2015}} {{Use American English|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}
{{Paranormal |state=collapsed}} This is a '''list of reportedly haunted locations''' throughout the world, that are said to be haunted by [[ghost]]s or other [[supernatural]] beings, including [[demon]]s. Reports of haunted locations are part of ghostlore, which is a form of [[folklore]].
==Argentina== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''[[Cinco Saltos]]''' in [[Río Negro (Argentina)|Río Negro]] has been reported to have a number of ghosts, most of them reportedly the result of [[witchcraft]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://infinitomisterioso.blogspot.com.ar/2010/08/misterio-en-el-cementerio-la-ciudad-de.html |title=Misterio en el Cementerio La Ciudad De Cinco Saltos |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> In 2009, an intact corpse of an 8- to 12-year-old girl who had died in the 1930s was found in a cemetery [[ossuary]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www1.rionegro.com.ar/arch200310/s01g02.html |title=Polémica por una momia de Cinco Saltos|publisher=RioNegro.com.ar |date=2003-10-01 |accessdate=28 July 2013}}</ref>
==Australia== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Ararat Lunatic Asylum - Aradale Psychiatric Hospital.jpg|thumb|[[Aradale Mental Hospital|Ararat Lunatic Asylum]]]] * The '''''Buratimos''''' is the wreck of a former [[U.S. Navy]] ship from World War II, that occurred off the coast of [[Western Australia]] during 1964.<ref>Jack Wong Sue and Barry Sue. ''Ghost of the Buratimos''. (Revised edition: Perth, 2005)</ref> *'''[[Aradale Mental Hospital|Ararat Lunatic Asylum]]''', or Aradale, is the largest abandoned [[History of psychiatric institutions|lunatic asylum]] in Australia. Opened during 1867, Aradale was reserved for many of the incurable mental patients in Victoria during the 1800s. An estimated 13,000 people died here during 140 years of operation. * Thirteen people were executed at the '''[[Ballarat Gaol]]''' in [[Ballarat]]. The remains of seven criminals are still on the grounds. The Ballarat Ghost Tours operate nightly.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eerietours.com.au |title=Eerietours.com.au |publisher=Eerietours.com.au |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> *'''[[Beechworth Asylum|Beechworth Lunatic Asylum]]''' in [[Beechworth, Victoria]] is reportedly haunted by several ghosts of departed patients. Open from 1867 to 1995, it has appeared in several books, television shows, and documentaries, including ''A.C.T. Paranormal''. Ghost tours run nightly.<ref>[http://www.beechworth.com.au/Beechworth-Tours/Beechworth-Tours/Beechworth-Ghost-Tours-Bookings.html Beechworth Ghost Tours - Information] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217024800/http://beechworth.com.au/Beechworth-Tours/Beechworth-Tours/Beechworth-Ghost-Tours-Bookings.html |date=17 February 2011 }} Accessed 6/9/08</ref> * '''[[Brisbane City Hall]]''' in [[Brisbane|Brisbane, Australia]] has several stories of deaths spanning the eras before and after its construction. During construction, workmen were said to have died while laying the foundations, which were on top of a former swamp. It is also said that the area was once a significant Aboriginal site – either a meeting place or campground. One story relates the death of a maintenance man, or lift attendant, who either fell to his death down the lift well or was crushed by the lift – this story likely results from a suicide from the clock tower that occurred during 1935.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hauntsofbrisbane.blogspot.com.au/2011/10/brisbane-city-hall-liftman-was-innocent.html|title=The Haunts of Brisbane: Brisbane City Hall: The Liftman was innocent.|author=Liam Baker|publisher=}}</ref> Another story claims an American soldier was stabbed to death during World War II during a fight. Staff have reported the sounds of an argument from the Red Cross Tea Room, and there are many reports of sounds and unusual activity in the areas surrounding these deaths. A third story claims the apparition of a woman is regularly seen traversing the main stairs in the lobby, and to look out over the foyer – a story which likely results from another suicide from City Hall's Clock Tower during 1937, although recent photos of the stairwell exhibit a possible apparition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hauntsofbrisbane.blogspot.com.au/2012/07/female-phantom-of-bribane-city-hall-who.html|title=The Haunts of Brisbane: The Female Phantom of Bribane City Hall: Who is she, exactly?!?|author=Liam Baker|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:The BuzzSaw viewed from the entrance to Dreamworld..jpg|thumb|200px|[[BuzzSaw (roller coaster)|BuzzSaw roller coaster]] in Dreamworld.]] * '''[[Dreamworld (Australian theme park)|Dreamworld]]''' is a theme park in [[Coomera, Queensland]]. One building inside the grounds of the theme park, where the reality television series ''[[Big Brother Australia]]'' is produced, has been reported to be haunted since the show's first season during 2001. Numerous production staff claim to have witnessed the presence of a young girl, as well as a child's voice and fog appearing late at night and early in the morning.<ref>{{cite web | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130902213833/http://www.bigbrother.com.au/news/8715707/the-big-brother-housemate-youve-yet-to-meet | url = http://www.bigbrother.com.au/news/8715707/the-big-brother-housemate-youve-yet-to-meet | title = The Big Brother Housemate You’ve Yet To Meet ... | archivedate = 2013-09-02 | date = 2013-08-31 | accessdate = 2015-02-17}}</ref> Additionally, theme park employees have spoken about sightings of a ghost nicknamed [[Jack Darke]], named after a [[gold prospecting|gold prospector]] who was claimed to have been killed by a buzzsaw during 1897.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jVxSdym8Kg | title = Dreamworld Ghost Video | date = 18 August 2011}}</ref> *'''[[Monte Cristo Homestead]]''' in [[Junee, New South Wales]] was the site of seven deaths during the 1800s, and is reported{{By whom|date=October 2012}} to be the most haunted house in Australia. Various ghost groups have reported sightings there.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.montecristo.com.au/ |title=Monte Cristo Homestead, Australia's Most Haunted House – Ghost Tours |publisher=Montecristo.com.au |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> * '''[[North Head Quarantine Station]]''' in [[Manly, New South Wales]] housed victims of a number of diseases including [[smallpox]] and the [[Spanish influenza|Spanish flu]] between 1833 and 1984. It was the site of over 500 deaths. A number of ghost tours are run on the grounds, which includes a large cemetery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quarantinestation.com.au/Ghost-Tours/overview-ghost-paranormal-tours.html|title=(Quarantine Station Ghost Tours)|author=Kelly|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Port Arthur, Tasmania|Port Arthur]]''' in [[Tasmania]] operate nightly ghost *The '''[[Princess Theatre, Melbourne|Princess Theatre Melbourne]]''' has reported several ghosts since the building opened during 1886. The theatre's best known "inhabitant" is Frederick Baker, whose stage name was [[Frederick Federici]], a talented bass-baritone singer who died during March 1888 whilst singing the role of [[Mephistopheles]] in [[Faust (opera)|''Faust'']] – and who was seen by the rest of the cast taking his bows with them soon thereafter. For years the theater kept a seat vacant in the [[dress circle]] for Federici (only ceasing the practice on economic grounds), and his appearance in the dress circle during rehearsals for a new show is considered a good omen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/rewind/txt/s1184926.htm |title=Rewind (ABC TV): The theater ghost |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2004-08-29 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
==Bangladesh== {{main|Ghosts in Bengali culture#Alleged haunted places}} * '''[[Dhaka]] Airport Road''': The segment of the road between Nikunjo and Biman office is reported by believers to be haunted by a lady at night, supposedly causing accidents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/weekend/2015/oct/29/urban-legends-where-they-roam-restless|title=Urban legends: Where they roam restless|website=dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Dhaka Golf Heights, Banani, [[Dhaka]]''': Claimed by believers to be haunted by a crying baby, and feelings of being watched are reported.<ref name="dhakatribune.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/weekend/2015/oct/29/urban-legends-where-they-roam-restless|title=Urban legends: Where they roam restless|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Under-construction apartment in Old DOHS, Banani, [[Dhaka]]''': Said to have ties to [[Satanism]]. Lanes 4 and 5 are reputed to have been built on top of graves.<ref name="daily-sun.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/86647/HAUNTED-TALES:-IN-CONVERSATION-WITH-%E2%80%98DHAKA-PARANORMAL-SOCIETY%E2%80%99|title=HAUNTED TALES: IN CONVERSATION WITH ‘DHAKA PARANORMAL SOCIETY’|website=daily-sun.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Purbo Nayatola Rail Crossing, [[Dhaka]]''': Reported by believers to be haunted by a woman frantically looking for her missing infant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/weekend/2015/oct/29/urban-legends-where-they-roam-restless#sthash.KHLIvOWN.dpuf|title=Urban legends: Where they roam restless|website=dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''[[Shahidullah Hall]] Pond, Dhaka''': The old pond adjoining Shahidullah Hall at [[Dhaka University]] campus is believed to be haunted by people who drowned in the pond.<ref>{{Cite web|title=শহীদুল্লাহ হলের রহস্যময় পুকুর|url=http://www.bd-pratidin.com/campus/2015/04/12/74534|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> * '''Farmhouse in [[Narsingdi District|Narsingdi]]''': This farmhouse, over a couple of hundred years old, contains twin ponds called ''Bhobani'' and ''Rukshar'', and rumours claim of a Hindu cremation ground on site of one of the ponds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/weekend/2014/jan/31/paranormal-activity|title=Paranormal activity|website=dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Highway Near Mirsharai, [[Chittagong]]''': The highway connecting Dhaka and Chittagong near Mirsharai, Chittagong is claimed by believers to be haunted by a [[vanishing hitchhiker]] at night.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghoststoriesworld.com/haunted-places-in-bangladesh/the-highway-near-mirsharai-chittagong|title=The highway near Mirsharai Chittagong - Haunted Places in Bangladesh|last=Writer|first=Ghost|website=Ghoststoriesworld.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Pakri Beach, [[Chittagong]]''': This silver sand beach has a reputation of being haunted. Reported hauntings range from mysterious footsteps and disembodied screams to an apparition of an old sailor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghoststoriesworld.com/haunted-places-in-bangladesh/parki-beach-chittagong-ghost-stories|title=Parki Beach Chittagong Ghost stories, Apparitions of old sailors|last=Writer|first=Ghost|website=Ghoststoriesworld.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> [[File:Sunrise at Kuakata beach.JPG|thumbnail|200px|Kuakata Beach, Barisal]] * '''[[Kuakata| Kuakata Beach, Barisal]]''': [[Rakhine people|Rakhaine]] settlers claim this beach to be haunted. Believers also claim of a large, wooden, gold-laden boat in the surrounding forest area that is supposedly cursed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://remit2homeblog.wordpress.com/2013/12/30/kuakata-the-daughter-of-the-ocean-sagar-kanya/|title=Kuakata: The daughter of the ocean (Sagar Kanya)|last=Blog|first=Klinnk|website=Remit2Home|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> * '''Farmhouse in [[Comilla]]''': A huge farmhouse in Comilla is reported to be haunted by [[Shadow people|black shadows]] assaulting people at night.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/brush-with-the-paranormal-49233|title=Brush with the paranormal|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref>
==Barbados== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''[[Chase Vault]]''' is a [[burial vault (tomb)|burial vault]] in the cemetery of the [[Christ Church Parish Church]] in [[Oistins]], [[Christ Church Parish, Barbados|Christ Church]], [[Barbados]] best known for a widespread but unverified legend of "mysterious moving [[coffin]]s". According to the story, each time the heavily sealed vault was opened during the early 19th century for burial of a family member, all of the lead coffins had changed position. The facts of the story are unverified, and skeptics call the tale "historically dubious." The tale appears to have originated from anecdotes told by Thomas H. Orderson, Rector of Christ Church during the 1800s, and subsequently repeated in [[James Edward Alexander]]'s 1833 ''Transatlantic Sketches.''<ref name="Alexander1833">{{Cite book|author=Sir James Edward Alexander|title=Transatlantic sketches, comprising visits to the most interesting scenes in North and South America, and the West Indies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t74NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA162|year=1833|publisher=R. Bentley|pages=162–}}</ref><ref name="Percy1833">{{Cite book|author=Reuben Percy|title=The Mirror of literature, amusement, and instruction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7boRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA51|year=1833|publisher=J. Limbird|pages=51–}}</ref><ref name="Clark1999">{{Cite book|author=Jerome Clark|title=Unexplained!: Strange Sightings, Incredible Occurrences & Puzzling Physical Phenomena|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=szFLs6pQmsQC&pg=PA573|year=1999|publisher=Visible Ink Press|isbn=978-1-57859-070-4|pages=573–}}</ref><ref>Nickell, Joe; 1982. "Barbados' restless coffins laid to rest". ''[[Fate Magazine|Fate]]'', Part I, 35.4 (April): 50–56; Part II, 35.5 (May): 79–86</ref><ref name="Nickell2001">{{Cite book|author=Joe Nickell|title=Real-Life X-Files: Investigating the Paranormal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Bm-EjjG3AwC|accessdate=14 May 2012|date=24 October 2001|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=978-0-8131-2210-6}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated125">{{Cite book | last = Dils | first = Tracy | title = "Real-Life Scary Places":Terrifying True Tales | publisher = Willowisp Press | year= 1985 | location = [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] | page = 125 | isbn = 0-87406-794-4 }}</ref><ref name="ghost-story1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghost-story.co.uk/stories/thechasevault.html |title=Ghost Story.uk |publisher=Ghost-story.co.uk |date= |accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref>
==Brazil== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * The '''[[Joelma Building]]''' (now the Praça da Bandeira Building) in [[São Paulo]] is allegedly haunted by victims of the fire that started on 1 February 1974, after an air conditioning unit on the twelfth floor overheated; centered on the "Mystery of the Thirteen Souls", individuals who died within an elevator as they were trying to escape the fire, and are haunting the building.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Carolina Iskandarian Do G1, em São Paulo |url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/SaoPaulo/0,,MUL330153-5605,00.html |title=G1 Edição São Paulo – NOTÍCIAS – Lugares 'mal-assombrados' viram lenda em SP |publisher=G1.globo.com |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
==Cambodia== *'''[[Kampong Chhnang Province|Kampong Chhnang]]''': The famous "ghost house" in Cambodia.<ref name="Indochina"/>
==Canada== {{Main|List of reportedly haunted locations in Canada}} Several sites in Canada are reputedly haunted, including '''[[Citadel Hill (Fort George)]]''' in Halifax.
==China== {{main|List of reportedly haunted locations in China}} [[File:Front elevation, 81 Chaonei, Beijing.jpg|thumb|Western (front) elevation of [[Chaonei No. 81]] during 2014]] Several sites in China are reputedly haunted, including '''[[Chaonei No. 81]]''', an abandoned mansion in Beijing's [[Chaoyangmen]] neighborhood, and the '''[[Wukang Mansion]]''', formerly known as the ''Normandie Apartment'', in [[Shanghai]] (named after the [[World War I]] battleship Normandie). {{Clear}}
==Colombia== {{Main|List of Reportedly Haunted Locations in Colombia}}
==Czech Republic== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''[[Zvíkov Castle]]''': Until 1597 there are stories about a Zvíkovský Rarášek (Rarach is a supernatural being common in Slavic folklore, similar to an imp or trickster) which haunts people in the ancient tower, Markomanka. This tower has stones engraved with unknown symbols, and was built during the [[Marcomanni]] rule over [[Bohemia]], in the 1st century BC and 2nd century AD. It was integrated into Zvíkov castle hundreds of years later. Weird events occur here frequently, including weird photos, technical problems, unpredictable behaviour of animals, spontaneous extinguishing of fires, electromagnetic anomalies, and the presence of ghosts. In Czech media it's a popular subject of investigation. Other areas of the castle are also haunted; it is said to be dangerous to sleep in the main tower, with anyone who does dying within a year. Another monster common in Czech culture, [[fire hound]]s are also part of the myths surrounding the castle. It is said that these spectral dogs (in some accounts they are depicted with burning eyes) are guarding a hidden tunnel underneath Zvíkov.<ref>{{cite web |author=Galileo Corporation s.r.o. |url=http://www.hrad-zvikov.eu/points-of-interest/hliza-tower/ |title=Oficiální stránky hradu Zvíkov - Hlíza tower |publisher=Hrad-zvikov.eu |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325192456/http://www.hrad-zvikov.eu/points-of-interest/hliza-tower/ |archivedate=25 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.castlesandmanorhouses.com/summary.php?Category=Visit&Type=%28All+Properties%29&Country=%28All+Countries%29&Parameter=ByCountry |title=List of (All Properties) to Visit in (All Countries) |publisher=Castlesandmanorhouses.com |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blesk.cz/clanek/celebrity/10200/zvikovsky-rarasek-trapi-filmare.html |title=Zvíkovský rarášek trápí filmaře |publisher=Blesk.cz |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014 |language=Czech}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tajemnamista.cz/magazin/64-zvikovska-vez-markomanka-dodnes-vyhrozuje-smrti |title=Zvíkovská věž Markomanka: Dodnes vyhrožuje smrtí! |publisher=Tajemná místa |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014 |language=Czech |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327234202/http://www.tajemnamista.cz/magazin/64-zvikovska-vez-markomanka-dodnes-vyhrozuje-smrti |archivedate=27 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://paranormal.komis-site.eu/zvikov-tajemna-vez-markomanka/ |title=Zvíkov – Tajemná věž Markomanka « Paranormal |publisher=Paranormal.komis-site.eu |date=2013-01-24 |accessdate=26 March 2014 |language=Czech}}</ref>
==Denmark== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''[[Dragsholm Castle]]''' in [[Zealand]] is said to be haunted by the ghost of [[James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell]], imprisoned there for about five years until his death during 1578.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guide-to-castles-of-europe.com/dragsholm-castle.html |title=Guide to castles of Europe |accessdate=31 October 2007}}</ref>
==Egypt== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:WhiteDesertEgypt@FarafraOasis2007jan6-93 byDanielCsorfoly.JPG|thumb|Farafra Desert]] *'''[[Baron Empain Palace]]''': Tourists have reportedly heard voices throughout the palace late at night. Guards and police have reported seeing ghostly apparitions of people who were once residents of the palace, wandering the outside lawn at midnight.<ref name="autogenerated359">{{cite book |page=359 |title=Encyclopedia of Haunted Places: Ghostly Locales from Around the World |author=Jeff Belanger |publisher= New Page Books |year=2005 |ISBN=1564147991}}</ref> *'''[[Farafra, Egypt|Farafra Desert]]''': The ghost of [[Akhenaten]] is said to wander the Farafra Desert (also known as the White Desert) of Egypt, reported by dozens of tourists and [[nomads]]. Legend says this is because Akhenaten abolished the Egyptian gods when he became Pharaoh, angering the religious followers and priests of Egypt. Upon his death, the priests are believed to have cursed him to wander the deserts forever as punishment.<ref>{{cite book |page=1 |title=The Ghost of Akhenaten |author=Moyra Caldecott |publisher=Mushroom Publishing |year=2003 |ISBN=1-84319-024-9}}</ref> *'''[[Pyramids of Giza]]''': A man in early 20th-century clothing has been seen by visitors, rumored to be the ghost of [[Howard Carter]]. Various employees and tourists have reported seeing an [[orb (optics)|orb]] apparition of an Egyptian Pharaoh, floating away from the pyramids towards the Valley of the Kings.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> *'''[[Valley of the Kings]]''': Eyewitnesses have reported seeing the vision of an Egyptian Pharaoh in the Valley of the Kings, wearing his golden collar, headdress, and riding a fiery [[chariot]] with black phantom horses.<ref name="autogenerated359"/>
==Finland== *'''[[Alexander Theatre]]''' in [[Helsinki]] is reportedly haunted by the ghost of an officer. The ghost moved to Helsinki as the tiles to build Alexander Theatre were relocated from [[Åland]]. Some have suggested that the officer died in the [[Crimea War]] and has been there ever since.<ref name=Fin>[http://www.nopsatravels.com/kummitusten-helsinki/#kohde2 Kummitusten Helsinki ] Retrieved 22 December 2015</ref> *'''[[Finnish National Theatre]]''' in Helsinki is reportedly haunted by at least three ghosts - an unknown ''Grey Lady'' and the ghosts of actors [[Aarne Leppänen]] and [[Urho Somersalmi]].<ref name=Fin/> *'''Haihara Manor''' in [[Tampere]] is haunted by ''The Blue Maid'', former maid of the manor.<ref>[http://www.tampere.fi/english/culturalaffairs/locations/haihara/history.html City of Tampere - History] Retrieved 22 December 2015</ref> *'''Mustio Manor''' in the village of Mustio reportedly is a location with several ghosts.<ref>[http://www.mustionlinna.fi/en/museum-a-park/museum-a-park/museum-guided-tour Museum & Guided Tour of Mustion Linna Website ] Retrieved 22 December 2015</ref> *'''Svenska Klubben''' (The Swedish Club) house in [[Kruununhaka]], Helsinki, is haunted by the ''Grey Madame''. She is rumoured to be the former lady of the house who had an affair with her chauffeur. She is known to swing the chandeliers, play piano and walk around the house.<ref>[http://www.mtv.fi/lifestyle/koti/artikkeli/urho-vaeltaa-teatterissa-kirves-kadessaan-lahde-kierrokselle-helsingin-kuuluisiin-kummitustaloihin/5219666 MTV Lifestyle] Retrieved 22 December 2015</ref> *'''[[Turku City Library]]''' employees have reportedly had paranormal experiences in the basement of the library. The ghost is assumed to be a former librarian.<ref [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185506/http://www2.hs.fi/klik/kummitus2001/kummitus.html >Kummitus kävi taloksi - Helsingin Sanomat ] Retrieved 22 December 2015</ref> *'''[[Villa Kleineh]]''', a historical villa in Helsinki currently used by the Dutch embassy, reportedly hosts a ghost called ''The White Lady''.<ref name="HT 2013">{{cite web | author=HT | title=Villa Kleineh opens on Restaurant Day to serve cuisine hollandaise | website=News from Finland "Helsinki Times" | date=14 November 2013 | url=http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/eat-and-drink/8389-villa-kleineh-opens-on-restaurant-day-to-serve-cuisine-hollandaise.html | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref>
==France== {{Main|List of reportedly haunted locations in France}} [[File:Logis chateau chateaubriant 01.jpg|thumb|[[Château de Châteaubriant]]]]
Several sites in France are reputedly haunted, including the '''[[Château de Brissac]]''', the '''[[Château de Trécesson]]''' in Brittany, the '''[[Catacombs of Paris|Catacombs]] ''' and '''[[Père Lachaise Cemetery|Cemetery of Père Lachaise]]''' in Paris, '''[[Mont Saint-Michel]]''', and the '''[[Château de Châteaubriant]]''' in western [[France]]. {{Clear}}
==Germany== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''Berlin''': The [[Reichstag building]] has been reported to be haunted by numerous ghosts of famous German politicians.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> *'''[[Heidelberg]]''': The ''Hexenturm'' ([[Witches Tower]]) and the [[Nazi]] Amphitheatre are both said to be haunted by various ghosts.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> *'''[[Frankenstein Castle]]''': Frankenstein Castle ({{lang-de|Burg Frankenstein}}) is a real [[hilltop castle]] in the [[Odenwald]], overlooking the city of [[Darmstadt]], and allegedly an inspiration for [[Mary Shelley]] when she wrote her monster novel ''[[Frankenstein]]''. The [[SyFy]] TV show ''[[Ghost Hunters International]]'' aired an entire episode about the castle and testified it had "... significant paranormal activity".<ref>[http://www.syfy.com/ghosthuntersinternational/episodes/season/s01/episode/e107/frankenstein_s_castle SyFy - Ghost Hunters International Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420024220/http://www.syfy.com/ghosthuntersinternational/episodes/season/s01/episode/e107/frankenstein_s_castle |date=20 April 2014 }} Retrieved 19 April 2014</ref> *'''Lichtenegg Castle''': The ghost of a lady in a white dress is said to be seen standing in front of the entrance to the ruins at midnight. She will, usually, sit down on a flat rock covered with moss.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> [[File:Nordkirchen-Hauptgebaeude-von-Venusinsel-DSC 5912.jpg|thumb|Northern front of Schloss Nordkirchen.]] *'''[[Schloss Nordkirchen]]''': The castle was built between 1703 and 1734. According to the legend, at full moon and on certain foggy nights, a few people have reported seeing a luxurious [[carriage]] with stallions running through the grounds.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> *'''[[Wolfsegg, Bavaria]]''', '''Wolfsegg Castle''': This 14th-century castle was supposed to be a sanctuary for travellers. The folklore of this haunting originated from the 1500s, when Ulrich von Laaber hired two young farmers to kill his wife, Klara von Helfenstein, after discovering she was having an affair. Soon thereafter, Ulrich and his sons also died suddenly. There have been reports of strange noises coming out of a cave area near the castle. Several expeditions into the cave, uncovering numerous animal skeletons, leading locals to decide the noises had come from hunters who were hiding their prey. While the cave noises might have been solved, this has not been the case of the haunting of the "White Woman" who is still restlessly making her rounds of the castle.<ref name="autogenerated359"/> *'''[[Würzburg]]''': There is supposedly the ghost of a dead [[nun]] walking through the halls of Praemonstratenser Abbey. The ghost is said to be that of Maria Renata Von Mossau, accused of mixing herbs into everyone's food in order to bewitch them. The nun was taken to be executed only three days after her sentencing in court. She was first decapitated, and then burned and her ashes scattered. To this day, there are reports of her walking down the hallways and holding a bouquet of roses while picking off the petals, leaving a trail across the grounds.<ref name="autogenerated359"/>
==India== {{main|List of reportedly haunted locations in India}} [[File:South-Park-Street-Cemetery-1.jpg|thumb|South Park Street Cemetery.]] Several sites in India are reported to be haunted, including [[South Park Street Cemetery]] in West Bengal on [[Park Street, Kolkata]], and [[Morgan House, Kalimpong|Morgan House]], a colonial-era mansion in [[Kalimpong]] that is considered to be one of the most haunted locations in [[India]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/5-haunted-hotels-of-india-hotel-taj-mahal-palace-mumbai-hotel-brij-raj-bhavan-kota-morgan-house-tourist-lodge-kalimpong/1/532827.html|title=Dare to stay at these haunted hotels of India?|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Indonesia== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Basement of Lawang Sewu 2011.JPG|thumb|The basement of the Building B of Lawang Sewu, a former prison. It is one of the rooms where ghost sightings have been reported.]] *'''[[Dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo Hospital]]''': The government run hospital located at [[Salemba]], [[Jakarta]]. It is rumored to be haunted [[vengeful spirit]] nurse named ''Suster Ngesot''.<ref>{{cite web|language=thai|url=https://writer.dek-d.com/longhorn49/story/viewlongc.php?id=1311706&chapter=4|title=ตอนที่ 4: Suster Ngesot พยาบาลสาวสุดสยอง|date=2015-02-25|accessdate=2018-07-28|work=Dek-de.com|author=แสงอุสา}}</ref> *'''[[Jakarta History Museum]]''': This historical building once served as the administrative headquarters of the [[Dutch East Indies]]. The front square of the building was often used as a place of executions for criminals. During nighttime there are reports of sighting of a headless ghost, Dutch colonial lady, and mysterious sounds coming from the underground prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipwee.com/travel/kisah-misteri-yang-tersembunyi-di-museum-fatahillah-dijamin-kamu-bakal-merinding-dibuatnya/|title=Kisah Misteri yang Tersembunyi di Museum Fatahillah. Dijamin Kamu Bakal Merinding Dibuatnya!|first=Andina|last=Rahayu|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnindonesia.com/gaya-hidup/20141213145342-269-17920/riwayat-penjara-terpendam-di-kota-tua-jakarta/|title=Riwayat Penjara Terpendam di Kota Tua Jakarta|publisher=}}</ref> *'''[[Jeruk Purut Cemetery]]''': A cemetery in [[Jakarta]] said to be haunted by the ghost of a decapitated pastor, which carries its head around with it, and is followed by a large black dog. The story was used as the inspiration for the 2006 movie, ''[[Hantu Jeruk Purut]]''.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | year = | date=27 March 2010 | title = Ghost tales underline Jakartan love for absurdities | work = The Jakarta Post | location = Jakarta | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/03/27/ghost-tales-underline-jakartan-love-absurdities.html | accessdate=28 October 2011 | ref = {{harvid|The Jakarta Post 2010, Ghost tales underline}} }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Sembiring |first1=Dalih |last2=Siregar |first2=Lisa |year= |date=14 August 2009 |title=Spirits In the Night: A Guide to Jakarta's Ghosts |work=The Jakarta Globe |location=Jakarta |url=http://jakartaglobe.id/archive/spirits-in-the-night-a-guide-to-jakartas-ghosts |accessdate=28 October 2011 |ref={{harvid|Sembiring and Siregar 2009, Spirits in the night}} }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *'''[[Lawang Sewu]]''': Literally meaning a "thousand doors" in Javanese, it is a former Dutch colonial building located in Semarang, in central Java. Many ghost sightings have been reported here, including a ghost of a Dutch lady as well as headless ghouls. During one of the ghost hunting television programs, a ghost was purportedly caught on camera.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bym4TXmuy-o |title=Dunia Lain Lawang Sewu}}</ref> *'''[[Parangtritis]]''': This popular tourist beach located in southern coast of [[Special Region of Yogyakarta|Yogyakarta]] contains legend regarding the foundation of the [[Mataram Sultanate]]. It was said that here [[Sutawijaya|Panembahan Senopati]], the founder of Mataram Sultanate made a spiritual pact with [[Nyai Roro Kidul]], the ruler of Java's southern sea for the well-being of Mataram. Every year, the ''Labuhan'' ceremony is held there and in neighboring Parangkusumo beach to commemorate the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wisatalicious.com/pantai-parangtritis-yogyakarta-keindahan-yang-berbalut-misteri/|title=Pantai Parangtritis Yogyakarta, Keindahan Yang Berbalut Misteri - Wisatalicious|website=wisatalicious.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.okezone.com/read/2014/03/16/510/956019/cerita-ratu-kidul-kesemsem-panembahan-senopati|title=Cerita Ratu Kidul|publisher=}}</ref> *'''[[Pelabuhan Ratu]]''': Legend says that [[Nyai Roro Kidul]] (Nyai is a [[Javanese language|Javanese]] and [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]] honorific for Madame), the Queen of the South Sea and daughter of King Prabu Siliwangi, is supposed to have committed suicide by jumping off the cliff into the sea. Rumors say that if someone wears green when swimming (the Queen's favourite color), he or she will be pulled by her ghost into the sea. Room 308 at the [[Samudra Beach Hotel]] is set aside for the Queen's ghost.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mikalina.com/Texts/pelabuhanratu_indonesia.htm |title=Pelabuhanratu (Indonesia) – A resort with a ghost |accessdate=20 December 2006 |last=Janssen |first=Peter |publisher=MysticAsia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061124200111/http://www.mikalina.com/Texts/pelabuhanratu_indonesia.htm |archivedate=24 November 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://indahnesia.com/indonesia/JAWSAM/samudra_beach.php |title=Room No. 308 still retains its mystery |accessdate=20 December 2006 |last=Khouw |first=Ida Indawati |publisher=The Jakarta Post}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Ireland== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:IMG KinnittyCastle0973.jpg|thumb|Kinnitty Castle]] [[File:Malahide Castle - magic door.JPG|thumb|Malahide Castle]] [[File:The Stewards House Killakee.jpg|thumb|Stewards House, Montpelier Hill]] *'''[[Charles Fort (Ireland)|Charles Fort]]''': Haunted by a 17th-century bride known as "The White Lady of Kinsale".<ref>{{cite web|author=JackMc |url=http://www.europeanghostsandhauntings.com/2011/12/white-lady-of-kinsale-charles-fort-near.html |title=White Lady of Kinsale - Charles Fort near Kinsale, Ireland |publisher=European Ghosts and Hauntings |date=2011-12-03 |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Charleville Castle]]''': This castle is haunted by the third [[Earl of Charleville]]'s younger daughter, Harriet. She lost her life after falling from the main staircase of this building at the age of eight, in April 1861.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghost-story.co.uk/index.php/most-haunted/191-charleville-castle-tullamore-ireland |title=Charleville Castle, Tullamore, Ireland |publisher=Ghost-story.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> It was featured on ''[[Scariest Places on Earth]]'', ''[[Most Haunted]]'', and ''Ghost Hunters International''. *'''Drumbeg Manor''' in Inver, Donegal: Considered to be one of the most haunted places in all Europe. Apparitions and strange events are reported to have taken place within the manor, and on its grounds. Stories say that a screaming woman can be heard, as well as the appearance of a man in a white suit walking the halls.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paranormaldatabase.com/ireland/cork.php?pageNum_paradata=2&totalRows_paradata=116 | title=Ghosts, Hauntings and Legends |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref> *'''[[Ducketts Grove]]''': The mansion was owned by the Duckett family for 300 years, and is said to be haunted by a [[Banshee|Banshee Ghost]]. On 17 March 2011, the [[SyFy]] show ''Destination Truth'' featured a four-hour live investigation for the season finale to find out the mystery of the ruins.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.syfy.com/destinationtruth/episodes/season/4.5/episode/409/destination_truth_live_event| title=Destination Truth: Duckett's Grove|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref> *'''[[Kilmainham Gaol]]''': This former prison has paranormal activities of lights which often turn themselves on and off in the prison's chapel, unseen forces pushing people over, apparitional footsteps, the feeling of being watched by spirits, as well as unexplained bangs and disembodied voices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hauntedrooms.co.uk/kilmainham-gaol |title=Kilmainham Gaol - Dublin, Ireland |publisher=HauntedRooms.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Kinnitty Castle]]''': This Gothic castle sits on a plot that once housed [[Druid]]s and [[Bards]]. It has witnessed a long and turbulent history, and is reportedly the home of many ghosts, the most popular of which is the Phantom Monk of [[Kinnitty]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hauntedrooms.co.uk/kinnitty-castle-hotel-co-offaly-ireland| title=Ghosts of Kinnitty Castle Hotel |accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> It was featured on ''Most Haunted''. *'''[[Malahide Castle]]''': This castle is haunted by Lord Galtrim, Sir Walter Hussey, the son of the Baron of Galtrim. Killed in battle on his wedding day during the 15th century, his apparition roams the castle at night, groaning in pain, while pointing at the spear wound in his side. There is also Lady Matilda "Maud" Plunkett. Her spirit appears to workers and guests as she did on the day of her marriage to the Lord Chief Justice. Maud would chase his spirit through the corridors. The third spirit is Puck, a jester who fell in love with [[Gearóid Mór FitzGerald, 8th Earl of Kildare|Gerard FitzGerald]]'s daughter, Lady Eleanor, who was detained at the castle by Henry VIII for inciting rebellions. One snowy night in December, Puck was found stabbed through the heart, still wearing his jester suit and cap. Before his death, he swore that he would haunt here until a master with a bride from the people ruled this castle. However, he promised not to harm any male Talbot who slept here. Numerous visitors have reported seeing the jester's face on some photos taken here. The White Lady is the fourth apparition here. The White Lady is a painting of a very beautiful, but unknown, lady which hangs on the castle's Great Wall. It is said that she would leave her painting at times and wander through the grounds at night. The fifth and final spirit is [[Miles Corbet]]. He was given this castle and the surrounding property by Oliver Cromwell. During the Restoration, Miles was made to pay for his crimes, and was hanged. It is reported that his apparition appears as a whole soldier in armour which then suddenly fall into pieces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hauntedrooms.co.uk/malahide-castle|title=Haunted Weekends, Haunted Hotels & Haunted Castles|work=Haunted Rooms|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Montpelier Hill]]''': The Stewards House, or Killakee House, was built around 1765 by the Conolly family as a hunting lodge. The house has a reputation for being haunted. Stories tell of a particularly large ghostly [[black cat]]. The best documented account occurred between 1968 and 1970 when the ''[[Evening Herald]]'' and ''[[Evening Press]]'' newspapers carried a number of reports regarding a Mrs. Margaret O'Brien and her husband Nicholas, a retired [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] [[superintendent (police)|superintendent]], who were converting the house into an arts centre. During the conversion, tradesmen employed on the work site began complaining of ghosts. One night, a friend of the O'Briens, artist Tom McAssey, and two workmen were confronted by a spectral figure and a black cat with glowing red eyes. McAssey painted a portrait of the cat which hung in the house for several years afterwards. Although locals were skeptical of the reports, further apparitions were reported, most notably that of an Indian gentleman, and of two nuns called Blessed Margaret and Holy Mary who had taken part in black masses on Montpelier Hill. There were also reports of incorporeal ringing bells and [[poltergeist]] activity. In 1970, an [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] television crew recorded a documentary about the house. In the documentary, a [[clairvoyant]] called Sheila St. Clair communicated with the spirits of the house through [[automatic writing]]. In 1971, a plumber working in the house discovered a grave with a skeleton of a small figure, most likely that of a child or, perhaps, the body of the dwarf alleged to have been sacrificed by the members of the Hell Fire Club. The house operated as a restaurant in the 1990s before closing in 2001; it is now a private residence.<ref>{{cite book |last=O'Farrell |first=Padraic |title=Irish Ghost Stories |year=2004 |publisher=Gill & Macmillan |location=Dublin |isbn=978-0-7171-3633-9 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Walsh |first=Dave |title=Haunted Dublin |year=2008 |publisher=Nonsuch Publishing |location=Dublin |isbn=978-1-84588-932-6 }}</ref><ref name="Walsh_21">Walsh, p. 21.</ref> *'''[[Leap Castle]]''': Many people were imprisoned and executed in this castle, and it is supposedly haunted by several spirits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.castles.org/castles/Europe/Western_Europe/Ireland/Leap/Leap.htm |title=The Reference of the Castle |accessdate=14 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505062516/http://www.castles.org/castles/Europe/Western_Europe/Ireland/Leap/Leap.htm |archivedate=5 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It was featured on ''Scariest Places on Earth'' and ''Most Haunted''. *'''Renyle House Hotel''' in [[Galway]]: Haunted by former anonymous remaining guests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hauntedrooms.co.uk/renyle-house-hotel|title=Haunted Weekends, Haunted Hotels & Haunted Castles|work=Haunted Rooms|accessdate=4 October 2014}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *'''[[Ross Castle]]''': Guests often wake at night hearing disembodied voices and doors banging and shutting on their own. An apparitional spirit who roams here is Richard Nugent's daughter, Sabina. Her lover, Orwin drowned himself. A second apparitional spirit who roams here is Orwin's father, Myles "The Slasher" O'Reilly. This Irish soldier spent his last night here before dying in a battle in 1644.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ross-castle.com/en/history/ghosts |title=Ross Castle B&B - Ghosts |publisher=Ross-castle.com |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *'''[[St. Michan's Church]]''': This church is haunted by disembodied whispering voices from mummies entombed in the [[burial vault (tomb)|vault]]s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Strickler |first=Lon |url=http://www.phantomsandmonsters.com/2010/01/haunted-earth-mummies-of-st-michans.html |title=Pulse of the Paranormal |publisher=Phantoms and Monsters |date=2010-01-26 |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Shelbourne Hotel]]''': This hotel is believed to be haunted by a seven-year-old girl from the 18th century, named Mary Masters, who had lived in the row of houses which once stood where the hotel is now. She died due to cholera during 1791. Her apparition roams the halls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hauntedrooms.co.uk/shelbourne-hotel-dublin-ireland |title=Shelbourne Hotel, Dublin, Ireland |publisher=HauntedRooms.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Wicklow Gaol]]''': a prison for over 200 years, it is claimed to be haunted by many former prisoners.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ghostcatcherie.wordpress.com/2009/09/19/wicklow-gaol-the-gates-of-hell-september-2009-2/|title=Wicklow Gaol, ‘The Gates of Hell’, September 2009|date=19 September 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
==Italy== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''[[Colosseum]]''': Known also as the '''Flavian Amphitheatre''', was reported to be haunted according to some witnesses and researchers' testimonies. Visitors have described observing ghostly figures wandering the staircases. There have been reports of hearing the cheers and screams from a crowd while no sign of people in the particular section. The vaults were, reportedly, active by the spirits of [[gladiator]]s waiting to fight, [[actor]]s waiting to perform, and prisoners becoming prepared for execution. Several accounts of cold touches or pushes have been felt by both tourists and employees. Sounds of animals have also been heard within the vaults.<ref>{{cite web|last=J.Lynch |first=Gordon |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cFRsQu4LgHgC&pg=PA213&dq=Colosseum+haunted&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjCm_mWjI_OAhUB6iYKHcKDD6oQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=Colosseum%20haunted&f=false |title=Famous Ghosts and Haunted Places|publisher=Rosen Publishing Group Inc. |date=2012 |accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref> * The castle of '''Montebello''', in [[Montebello di Torriana]] (in the [[province of Rimini]]), is famous for the medieval legend that tells that an [[Albinism|albino]] (in the [[Middle Ages]], albino people was thought to be incarnations of [[Satan]]) girl nicknamed "Azzurrina" ([[Italian language|Italian]] feminine [[diminutive]] for "azzurro", "light [[blue]]", the colour of her eyes), born about in 1370 and mysteriously vanished on 21 June 1375 ([[solstice]] day), while her father, ''Signore'' ("Lord") of Montebello, was fighting in a battle. According to the legend, Azzurrina's ghost appears in the castle every five years from that day, on solstice day. The legend provided fame for the town of Montebello di Torriana and much tourism to the castle, especially on 21 June. *'''[[Poveglia]]''': This island, near Venice, was once a sanctuary to refugees during the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[Ottoman wars in Europe|conflicts]], and a hospice for sick patients throughout the centuries. It was detailed, from witnesses, haunted by many victims of the [[Bubonic plague|plague]]. In 1922, the island became home to a mental hospital, where a doctor, reportedly, experimented on patients with crude [[lobotomy|lobotomies]]. He later threw himself from the hospital tower after claiming he had been driven mad by the spirits of the island. The island has been featured on the paranormal shows ''[[Ghost Adventures]]'' and ''[[Scariest Places on Earth]]''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/10767781/Worlds-most-haunted-island-up-for-auction.html|title = 'World's most haunted island' up for auction|last = Kington|first = Tom|date = 15 April 2014|work = |accessdate = 16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/24658/strange-geographies-happy-haunted-island-poveglia|title=Strange Geographies: The Happy, Haunted Island of Poveglia|work=Mental Floss}}</ref> *'''[[Teatro Massimo]]''' in [[Palermo]].

Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Suicide Forest.jpg|thumb|Aokigahara in Yamanashi Prefecture]] *'''[[Hoichi the Earless|Amiidaji]]''' (Temple of [[Amitabha|Amida]]): In the [[Shimonoseki Strait]], it is the location of a legendary haunting. It is said that the blind [[Biwa hōshi]] Hoichi, a resident of the temple, was visited every night by the ghost of a dead samurai, and made to play the biwa in the cemetery. When the priest of the temple learned this, he had the [[heart sutra]] painted on every part of Hoichi's body apart from his ears. When the samurai returned to take Hoichi to the cemetery, he could only see Hoichi's ears, so he took them instead, leaving Hoichi earless, resulting his nickname, "Mimi-Nashi Hoichi" ([[Hōichi the Earless]]). This legend was famously retold by [[Lafcadio Hearn]] in his book ''[[Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things]]'', which was adapted as part of [[Masaki Kobayashi]]'s movie ''[[Kwaidan]]''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Professor Solomon |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=coxRQh_ONfIC&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=Hoichi+Dan-no-ura |title=Japan in a Nutshell}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/shi/kwaidan/kwai03.htm |title=The Story Of Mimi-Nashi-Hoichi |publisher=Sacred-texts.com |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> *'''[[Aokigahara]]''': The forest at the bottom of [[Mt. Fuji]] is a popular location for [[suicide]]. This results in a widespread belief that it is haunted. It was featured by an episode of ''Destination Truth'' on the SyFy Channel.<ref name="Iwasaka 1994">Iwasaka, Michiko and [[Toelken, Barre]]. ''Ghosts and the Japanese: Cultural Experiences in Japanese Death Legends'', Utah State University Press, 1994. {{ISBN|0-87421-179-4}}.</ref> * '''Okiku's Well''': The well at [[Himeji Castle]] is often said to be haunted by the ghost of [[Banchō Sarayashiki|Okiku]]. ==Netherlands== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Anne Frank House 02.JPG|thumb|200px|Anne Frank House]] [[File:Kasteel Waardenburg P1120541.jpg|thumb|Kasteel Waardenburg]] *'''[[Anne Frank House]]''', in [[Amsterdam]] is the former home of Anne Frank, the Dutch/Jewish girl who wrote the world-famous [[The Diary of a Young Girl]] the second world war. In this war, Anne and her family had to hide from the Germans, they did that in the now called [[Anne Frank House]]. Which, back in world war 2, was her father office. Anne, her sister and her mother later died in concentration camps. People nowadays say that they feel cold spots in the house, have the feeling of being watched and the staff sometimes hear sounds coming from the secret annex. They say that if you stand outside of the house at midnight you can see a little girl hanging out of the window. Many say the girl is Anne.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} *'''[[Singraven]][https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singraven]''', or Singraven Manor is an estate in [[Overijssel]], a province in The Netherlands. In the sixteenth century, Singraven Manor became the residence of some Franciscan nuns for a short time. One of the nuns got bricked up alive, and after that, many strange things started to happen. After the new owner arrived he was unexplainably set on fire by an oil lamp. People say that the bricked up nun is still haunting the estate today. *'''[[Hoensbroek Castle]]''', is a castle in the province of [[Limburg (Netherlands)|Limburg]]. In this castle there is said to be a ghost called the blue lady. Her official name was Anna Catherina and she died on 5 November 1760. People say that she is looking for her 2 children who died at an early age. The children where supposedly buried inside the castle walls while she wasn't informed. *'''[[Kasteel Waardenburg]][https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasteel_Waardenburg]''', or the Waardenburg castle is a castle in the province of [[Gelderland (Netherlands)|Gelderland]]. This castle is said to be one of the most haunted places in The Netherlands. People feel like they are being watched, hear footsteps and whispers, see things move and feel cold spots. people say that in medieval times the wizard who lived in the castle made a pact with the devil, that he could do and get whatever he wanted for a period of seven years and after that he would be taken by the devil. Till this day there are 2 bloodstains that can't be washed off on one of the castle walls that are the proof of this rumour. *'''[[De Blokhuispoort]][https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blokhuispoort]''', is an old building complex in the city of [[Leeuwarden]]. Blokhuispoort was originally built in 1499 as a citadel. Then it became a fortress, a court and execution place and from 1580 till 2007 it served as a prison. Nowadays it holds little businesses can hire workspace, a museum, a restaurant and the city's library. With that much history, it isn't weird that people claim it is haunted. People have seen objects move on their own, shadow people, doors closing on their own and locked doors opening, voices, people being touched and footsteps.
