==Singapore== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''[[Changi Hospital|Old Changi Hospital]]''': The vacated hospital compound was popular with movie-makers after the [[Singapore Land Authority]] commenced short term rental of the buildings and is often listed as one of Singapore's most haunted locations due to its history. A former British military hospital, its reputation as a haunted location likely stems from the [[Japanese occupation of Singapore|Japanese occupation]], when the ''[[Kempeitai]]'' used its premises as a prison camp and reportedly turned some of the rooms into a torture chamber.<ref>{{cite news|title=Places in Singapore with a dark past|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/places-in-singapore-with-a-dark-past|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=10 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=4 Haunted Places In Singapore So Spooky That Even The Ghosts Also Scared – Part 1|url=https://discoversg.com/2016/03/28/haunted-places-singapore-part-1/|publisher=Discover SG|first=Youliang|last=Teo|date=28 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Saving A Sexier Island: Notes from an Old Singapore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8qE9CgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=[[Marshall Cavendish]]|date=2015|first=Neil|last=Humphreys|author-link=Neil Humphreys}}</ref> *'''[[East Coast Park]]''': One night a couple was strolling around the area at night. It was at this tower where a group of thugs attacked them, knocking the boyfriend unconscious and killing the girlfriend after violating her. After this particular incident, there have been people claiming to have seen a female figure near the tower; while there have even been alleged screams of help resonating from the area.<ref>{{cite news|title=Haunted by unsolved murder of girlfriend 25 years ago|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/haunted-by-unsolved-murder-of-girlfriend-25-years-ago|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=19 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="All Singapore Stuff - Real Singapore News 2014">{{cite web | title=The Haunted Amber Beacon Tower at East Coast Park | website=All Singapore Stuff - Real Singapore News | date=10 June 2014 | url=https://www.allsingaporestuff.com/article/haunted-amber-beacon-tower-east-coast-park | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Pasir Ris Park]]''': One of the white sand beaches of Singapore. It is a place where it has been reported that a haunted place is a hotspot where women commit suicide. Nowadays, it is very popular among the ghost hunters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sea-globe.com/paranormal-ghosts-singapore-southeast-asia-globe/|title=Singapore’s ghost hunters|work=Southeast Asia Globe|first= David|last= Hutt|date=2015-10-09}}</ref>
==South Africa== {{main|List of reportedly haunted locations in South Africa}} Several locations in South Africa are reputedly haunted, including the [[Erasmus Castle]] in Pretoria and the [[Old Presidency]] in Bloemfontein.
==South Korea== *''' Gonjiam Psychiatric Hospital''': Famous for its very dark past among ghost hunters in [[Seoul]]. This abandoned hospital in [[Gwangju, Gyeonggi]] is claimed to be the most haunted place in Korea. The once psychiatric hospital is home to many rumors of ghosts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/gonjiam-psychiatric-hospital|title=Gonjiam Psychiatric Hospital|work=atlasobscura.com}}</ref> *'''Yeongdeok House''': An abandoned house on the hill of [[Yeongdeok County|Yeongdeok]] the seaside county, in the past used to be a [[Korean food|seafood restaurant]]. It is now a deserted house reputed as a haunted place. Believed to be the ghosts of teenage soldiers who died a number of Jangsa landing operation, a part of [[battle of Inchon]].<ref name="ผี"/> *'''[[Korean Folk Village]]''': The most popular tourist attraction is located [[Yongin]], [[Gyeonggi province]] has been reported to have witnessed [[Gwisin]] a [[vengeful ghost]] in the [[Korean folklore]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.traveller.com.au/tourists-terror-at-virgin-ghosts-25g9b|work=traveller.com|title=Tourists' terror at 'virgin ghosts'|date=2012-09-06|accessdate=2017-09-25}}</ref>
==Spain== [[File:Palacio de Linares - 01.jpg|thumb|[[Palace of Linares]]]] *'''[[Palace of Linares]]''' in [[Madrid]]: Built between 1872 and 1890 for the Marquis of Linares José de Murga. According to legend this place is the most haunted in Spain. Supposedly, a little girl appears in the mansion, the Marquis fathered her with his sister and they murdered her in order to hide their incestuous relationship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.madridvillaycorte.es/palacio-linares.php |title=Palacio de Linares |last1=Diehl Busch |first1=María Dolores |last2=Castañeda Velazquez |first2=Rafael |date= |website=Madrid, Villa y Corte |publisher=Ma. Dolores Diehl Busch |accessdate= 24 December 2014|language=Spanish |trans-title=Palace of linares}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ikerjimenez.com/reportajes/palaciodelinares/ |title= Una noche en el Palacio de Linares |last1=Vázquez |first1=Santiago |date= |website=ikerjimenez.com |publisher=Iker Jímenez |accessdate=24 December 2014|language=Spanish |trans-title=A night in the Palace of linares }}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Sweden== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> *'''Borgvattnets prästgård''': The rectory of the small village of [[Borgvattnet]] in [[Jämtland]], northern [[Sweden]], where there have been reports of hauntings since the early 1920s. Today, the rectory is open to the public, and people are allowed to spend up to two nights for a price. The Swedish TV Show, Det Okända, once went to the rectory for a visit, were unable to leave, and were forced to spend the night. There is also an infamous rocking chair, which stories are told of throwing a priest who once lived there on the floor multiple times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borgvattnet.eu/meraomprastgarden1.htm|title=Borgvattnets Spökprästgård mera om prästgården|website=www.borgvattnet.eu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paranormal.nu/borgvattnet.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102013048/http://www.paranormal.nu/borgvattnet.htm |archivedate=2 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *'''Toftaholm Herrgård''': The legend relates the story of a baron whose daughter was promised to a commoner, but the baron gave his daughter to someone else. On the day of the wedding, the commoner hanged himself from the rafters. The spirit of the commoner is said to wander Room 324, where the rafters once were.<ref><span class="plainlinks">[http://www.articlesphere.com/Article/Scary-Creatures-of-the-Night--Scariest-Hotels-in-the-World/165029 Toftaholm Herrgard]</span> on Articlesphere.com.</ref>
==Switzerland== * '''The house located in Junkerngasse no 54''' in [[Bern]] is said to be haunted. The origin of this belief is unknown. According to a story, around 12 and 1 am, the windows open and a headless woman appears, laughing in a creepy way. One Story tells that a woman dressed in black appears walking along the rooms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bernerzeitung.ch/region/bern/Zu-Besuch-im-Gespensterhaus-an-der-Junkerngasse/story/24871239|title=Bern: Zu Besuch im "Gespensterhaus" an der Junkerngasse - News Region: Bern & Region - bernerzeitung.ch|work=bernerzeitung.ch/|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref>
==Taiwan== * '''Chiayi Min-Hsiung Haunted House:''' Located in [[Chiayi City]], it was once the residence of the Liu family. It is probably one of the most recognized haunted house in Taiwan.<ref name="ipeen.com.tw">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipeen.com.tw/comment/165581|title=嘉義民雄鬼屋(劉家古厝)---練心臟之旅@Guinevere－iPeen 愛評網|website=iPeen 愛評網|access-date=2017-01-13}}</ref>
==Thailand== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | background color = | total_width = 299 | image1 = ThaiGovHouse 001.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Wat Kudi Dao, Ayutthaya 0311.jpg | caption2 = | footer = [[Government House of Thailand]] (''left'') and [[Wat Kudi Dao]], a part of [[Ayutthaya Historical Park]] (''right''). }} {{main|List of reportedly haunted locations in Thailand}}
Many sites in Thailand are reputedly haunted, including [[Government House of Thailand]], [[Phitsanulok Mansion]], [[Lumphini Park]], [[Sathorn Unique Tower]] (Bangkok), [[Ayutthaya Historical Park]], and [[Mahidol University]] in central, or [[Ko Lipe|Lipe]] in southern etc.
==United Arab Emirates== *'''[[Al Jazirah Al Hamra]]''': An abandoned fishing village near [[Ras al-Khaimah]] which is believed to be haunted by the presence of supernatural ''[[jinn]]s''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/national-day/our-guide-to-the-living-ghost-town-jazirat-al-hamra-ras-al-khaimah|title=Our guide to the living ghost town Jazirat Al Hamra, Ras Al Khaimah|work=The National|date=27 November 2014|accessdate=30 October 2015|first=Anna|last=Zacharias}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://khaleejtimes.com/wknd/editors-picks/Dubai-residents-recount-their-scariest-moments|title=Dubai residents recount their scariest moments|work=Khaleej Times|first=Rohit|last=Nair|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/xpress/dubai/news/revealed-uae-s-most-haunted-places-1.1609108 |title=Revealed: UAE’s most ‘haunted’ places |work=Gulf News |date=28 October 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2015 |first=Abhishek |last=Sengupta |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030065202/http://gulfnews.com/xpress/dubai/news/revealed-uae-s-most-haunted-places-1.1609108 |archivedate=30 October 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==United Kingdom== {{Main|Reportedly haunted locations in the United Kingdom}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | background color = | total_width = 299 | image1 = Tower of London at night 3.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Glamis Castle - geograph.org.uk - 916029.jpg | caption2 = | footer = Tower of London (''left'') and Glamis Castle (''right''). }} Many sites in the UK are reputedly haunted, including the [[Tower of London]], [[50 Berkeley Square]] (London), [[Belgrave Hall]], [[Arundel Castle]], and [[Bruce Castle]] in England, and [[Ardrossan Castle]], [[Fyvie Castle]], [[Glamis Castle]], and [[Stirling Castle]] in Scotland.
==United States== {{Main|List of reportedly haunted locations in the United States}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | background color = | total_width = 299 | image1 = Octagon House (Washington, D.C.) in 2012.JPG | caption1 = | image2 = Winchester Mystery House (entrance).jpg | caption2 = | footer = The Octagon in Washington, D.C. (''left''), and Winchester Mystery House in California (''right''). }} Many sites in the United States are reputedly haunted, including [[Dudleytown (Cornwall)|Dudleytown]] in Connecticut, the [[Cherry Hill (Albany, New York)|Cherry Hill Estate]] and [[112 Ocean Avenue|112 Ocean Avenue House]], (a.k.a. the Amityville Horror House) in New York, '''[[Cliveden (Benjamin Chew House)|Cliveden Manor]]''', the '''[[First Bank of the United States]]''', '''[[Fort Mifflin]]''', '''[[Library Company of Philadelphia|Library Hall]]''', '''[[Pennsylvania Hospital]]''', and '''[[Powel House]]''' in Pennsylvania, the [[The Octagon House (Washington, D.C.)|Octagon House]] (1801) and the [[White House]] in the District of Columbia, and '''[[El Adobe de Capistrano]]''' in California. {{clear right}}
==Vietnam== *'''300 Kim Mã''' in [[Hanoi]] is a building which was proposed to be the Bulgarian Embassy in Vietnam, but was abandoned for an unknown reason. After a murder near this bulding, the story of mysterious phenomenas including the ghost of a Western man is popularised across the nation. Now it is the property of [[Vietnamese government]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soha.vn/xa-hoi/ngoi-nha-ma-300-kim-ma-cham-den-tan-cung-bi-an-20150804091956978.htm|title="Ngôi nhà ma" 300 Kim Mã: Chạm đến tận cùng bí ẩn|language=Vietnamese|publisher=Soha|date=12 August 2015|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Côn Đảo]]''': The unfinished stone bridge in the deep jungle named "Ma Thiên Lãnh Bridge" is called by the locals "Ghost Bridge", which is a bridge built by over [[Côn Đảo Prison|300 prisoners]] who suffered a lot and died [[France–Vietnam relations|under French control]]. One villager saw a long haired male ghost in a white shirt and black pants watch him while he was drinking with a friend, and then disappear. And a female villager said she saw a woman wearing a white dress standing on a bridge alone at the dawn. She knew instantly that it was a [[hungry ghost]]. One woman says she had come across a ghost of two boys without a shirt. They forced her to give them dessert.<ref name="ผี">{{IMDb title|3253618|I Wouldn't Go in There}}</ref> *'''The Hui Mansion (now [[Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts]])''': One of the most mysterious places in [[Ho Chi Minh City]], located at 97 Phó Đức Chính Street, [[District 1, Ho Chi Minh City|District 1]]. People believe that the mansion is haunted by the ghost of Mr. Hui Bon Hoa's [[leprosy]] daughter.<ref name="Indochina"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://saigoneer.com/saigon-culture/1922-saigon-urban-legends-the-ghost-of-the-fine-arts-museum|title=Saigon Urban Legends: The Ghost of the Fine Arts Museum|author=Dang Bui|publisher=Saigoneer|date=8 May 2014|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> {{clear}}
==See also== {{Category see also|Reportedly haunted locations}} {{Commons category|Ghosts}} <!-- Note to editors: Entries should be in alphabetical order. --> *[[Ghost hunting]] *[[Haunted house]] *[[List of ghosts]] *[[List of ghost films]] *[[List of Ghost Adventures episodes|List of ''Ghost Adventures'' episodes]] (includes lists of reportedly haunted locations mostly in the United States that have been investigated) *[[List of Ghost Hunters episodes|List of ''Ghost Hunters'' episodes]] (includes lists of reportedly haunted locations in the United States that have been investigated) *[[List of Most Haunted episodes|List of ''Most Haunted'' episodes]] (includes lists of reportedly haunted locations in the United Kingdom and Ireland that have been investigated)
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Ghosts|state=expanded}}

{{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> There are numerous reportedly haunted locations in [[France]]. This list alphabetizes by region (including overseas regions and collectivities) these places and then alphabetically within each region (including overseas regions and collectivities).
==Regions== ===Brittany=== *'''[[Château de Trécesson]]''': has various paranormal legends according to believers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bretagne.com/fr/patrimoine/contes_et_legendes/trecesson |title=Legends of the ''Joueurs fantômes'' and the ''Manoir du Pied d'Ânon'' |publisher=Bretagne.com |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
===Île-de-France=== [[File:Shrine of the dead.jpg|thumb|200px|Crypt of the Sepulchral Lamp in the [[Catacombs of Paris]]]] *'''[[Catacombs of Paris]] ''': It is said to be haunted by strange orbs and human figures from different centuries.<ref name="paris365days2007"/> *'''[[Château de Versailles]]''': once home to the French royal family between 1682 and 1789, a few tourists and employees have reported seeing people in 18th-century clothing.<ref name="paris365days2007"/> [[File:Père Lachaise Cemetery @ Paris (30623063724).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Père Lachaise Cemetery]]]] *'''[[Père Lachaise Cemetery|Cemetery of Père Lachaise]]''': the largest cemetery in Paris, France; in the northeast part of the modern city, it is the most visited cemetery in the world, and is said to be one of the most haunted cemeteries in Europe.<ref name="paris365days2007"/>
===Normandy=== *'''[[Mont Saint-Michel]]''': ghostly sightings of monks wandering the area have been reported.<ref name="paris365days2007"/>
===Pays de la Loire=== [[File:Logis chateau chateaubriant 01.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Château de Châteaubriant]], said to be haunted by the ghost of [[Françoise de Foix]].]] *'''[[Château de Brissac]]''': legend says that Jacques de Brézé caught his wife, Charlotte, with another man, and in a fit of rage murdered them both.<ref name="paris365days2007">{{Cite web|first=|last=|url=http://paris365days.com/the-top-10-weird-places-in-france-you-didnt-know/|title=The Top 10 Weird Places in France You Didn’t Know|work = Paris365Days.com |date=2007–2010|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> *'''[[Château de Châteaubriant]]''': this castle in the [[Loire-Atlantique]] [[Departments of France|''département'']] of western [[France]] is said to be haunted by the ghost of [[Françoise de Foix]], a mistress of King [[Francis I of France|Francis I]]. According to the legend, she was locked in her bed chambers by her husband, Jean de Laval-Châteaubriant, Governor of Brittany, jealous of her relationship with the King. She died on 16 October 1537, rumored to have been either poisoned or bled to death.<ref>{{Cite web|first=|last=|url=http://www.pays-chateaubriant.fr/chateaubriant/menu_principal/visiter/chateau_de_chateaubriant/chambre_doree_de_francoise_de_foix|title=Chambre dorée de Françoise de Foix|language=French|publisher=Pays de Châteaubriant website|date=|accessdate=22 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130412202208/http://www.pays-chateaubriant.fr/chateaubriant/menu_principal/visiter/chateau_de_chateaubriant/chambre_doree_de_francoise_de_foix|archivedate=12 April 2013|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} This is a [[list of places where social nudity is practised]] in North America for recreation. As a philosophy, this practice is commonly referred to as [[naturism]]; the International Naturist Federation has affiliates in over 30 countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.inffni.org |title=International Naturist Federation |publisher=Inffni.org |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} However, most who indulge in this activity are likely not formal members of a naturist organization. This listing includes free beaches (clothing-optional beaches or [[nude beaches]]) and some private resorts. ==Anguilla== Nude bathing on beaches is illegal in Anguilla.{{cite web|url=http://www.anguillian.com/article/articleview/8101/1/140 |title=Police Report |accessdate=2016-06-23 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100331205225/http://www.anguillian.com/article/articleview/8101/1/140 |archivedate=March 31, 2010 |df= }}{{cite book|last=Reed|first=Susan K. |title=Caribbean Business Directory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y2LvAAAAMAAJ|edition=International|year=1993|publisher=Caribbean Imprint|isbn=978-976-8088-05-5|p=17}} * Captain's Bay is a secluded beach where people do bathe in the nude (illegally).{{cite book|title=Fodor's Affordable Caribbean|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gwRsAAAAMAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Fodor's Travel Publications|isbn=978-0-679-02559-7|page=36}} ==Antigua and Barbuda== * Hawksbill Bay, [[Antigua]]{{cite web|url=http://gocaribbean.about.com/od/bestcaribbeanbeaches/tp/Caribnudebeaches.htm |title=Top Caribbean Nude Beaches - Best Topless and Nude Beaches in the Caribbean |publisher=Gocaribbean.about.com |date=2012-04-09 |accessdate=2013-04-22}} ==The Bahamas== * Breezes Bahamas, [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]] used to allow nude bathing but as of January 2015 nudity is no longer allowed.{{Cite web | title = Naturism, nudism in Bahamas | last = Terp | first = Peter | work = spotnaked.com | date = 21 January 2015 | accessdate = 2016-07-27 | url = http://spotnaked.com/naturism-nudism-bahamas/3598/ | quote = }} ==Belize== Though Belizeans don't particularly frown on nudity, there are no official nude beaches in Belize. However, there are dozens of deserted out islands with beaches perfect for sunbathing in the buff.{{cite book|last1=Harris|first1=Richard |last2=O'Neal|first2=Catherine |title=Hidden Belize: Including Tikal, Copan, and the Cayes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-jQXt1duVIUC|year=2003|publisher=Ulysses Press|isbn=978-1-56975-373-6|page=79}} ==Canada== ===British Columbia=== British Columbia has thousands of kilometres of coastline and thousands of lakes, as well as millions of hectares of natural parks and undeveloped land. The vast majority of these areas are mostly uninhabited and nude swimming and sunbathing can be done with little concern for disturbing others. In the populated areas, particularly the [[Lower Mainland]], [[Greater Victoria]], and the [[Okanagan]], nudity is generally practiced only in certain established or isolated locations (usually beaches) and on private properties. [[File:Wreckbeach-ptgrey.jpg|thumbnail|200px|[[Wreck Beach]] from a distance.]] * [[Wreck Beach]] is the second largest clothing-optional beach{{Cite web | title = Nudists call for fewer clothed visitors at clothing-optional beaches | last = Goffin | first = Peter | work = The Globe and Mail | date = 21 July 2016 | accessdate = 2016-07-27 | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/nudists-call-for-fewer-clothed-visitors-at-clothing-optional-beaches/article31046020/ | quote = }} in North America with over 100,000 visitors each year. On the shore of the [[Georgia Strait]] and the north arm of the [[Fraser River]], it is part of [[Pacific Spirit Regional Park]], which is adjacent to the [[University Endowment Lands]], just west of the city limits of [[Vancouver]]. * [[Crescent Rock Beach]] in [[Surrey, British Columbia|Surrey]]; after political wrangling in 2006 nude sunbathing is now allowed.{{cite web | url = http://www.crescentrockbeach.org/ | title = Surrey's United Naturists|access-date=2015-08-23}} * Red Sands Beach in [[Nelson, British Columbia|Nelson]] is a nude beach used mainly by the locals. Camping is not permitted. * Three Mile Beach in [[Penticton, British Columbia|Penticton]] has traditionally been used as a clothing optional beach, but the legal status of nudists using the beach is unclear.{{Cite web | title = Court case could determine naturist use of Three Mile Beach | last = Arstad | first = Steve | work = infotel.ca | date = 8 July 2015 | accessdate = 2016-06-24 | url = http://infotel.ca/newsitem/court-case-could-determine-naturist-use-of-three-mile-beach/it21012 | language = | quote = }}{{Cite web | title = Complaints over beach bust - Penticton News | last = Pfeiffer | first = Deborah | work = castanet.net | date = July 30, 2015 | accessdate = 2016-06-24 | url = http://www.castanet.net/news/Penticton/145062/Complaints-over-beach-bust | quote = }} * Nipple Point in [[Salmon Arm]] is a rocky beach east of the town that sees occasional nude use.{{sfn|Woycke|2006|p=188}} * Little Tribune Bay,{{efn|Little Tribune Bay nude beach {{coord|49.520971| -124.643459|format=dms|display=inline}} }}near the [[Tribune Bay Provincial Park]] on [[Hornby Island]] is a clothing optional sandy/small round gravel beach, close to the Co-op, camping nearby.{{Cite web | title = Irresistible Weekend Getaway: escape to eclectic Hornby Island | author = | work = British Columbia Magazine | date = June 18, 2005 | accessdate = 2016-06-24 | url = http://www.bcmag.ca/hornby | quote = nude }} *Mission Flats Beach, [[Kamloops]]. From downtown head east to Mission Flats Road. Follow that for approximately five minutes until you pass the pulp mill. There will be a large sign on the north side of the road stating no trespassing but there is a trail system to the beach from there. If you drive 20 seconds beyond the sign there is a parking lot with trails to the beach. Expansive sandy beach early spring and late summer based on the rise and fall of water levels. Very popular with couples as well as singles. *Prior Lake on [[Vancouver Island]] near [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]].{{sfn|Woycke|2006|p=187}} From a backroad around [[Thetis Lake]], there is access to this smaller lake which features a secluded dock that is clothing optional. *Southern extremity of the beach (beyond the painted "nude" signs on fallen trees) at Witty's Lagoon Regional Park in Metchosin near [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]]. * Sol Sante Club is a naturist club located on a {{convert|175|acre|adj=on}} property near Cobble Hill, north of [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] on [[Vancouver Island]]. *At [[Lost Lake (Whistler)|Lost Lake]] in [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]], there is a "Nudy Dock" where it is acceptable to bathe and suntan nude.{{Cite web | title = The Naked Truth | last = Mitchell | first = Andrew | work = Pique | date = January 19, 2001 | accessdate = 2016-06-24 | url = http://www.piquenewsmagazine.com/whistler/the-naked-truth/Content?oid=2137001 | quote = }} ===Alberta=== * CottonTail Corner Naturist Beach, located 20 minutes from the City of Edmonton near the Town of Devon. A 25-minute hike through the trees leads to the beach.{{Cite news|url=http://cottontailcorner.ca/directions/|title=How do I get to CottonTail Corner?|work=CottonTail Corner|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-US}} * Helios Nudist Association, less than an hour's drive east of Edmonton, is billed as North America's northernmost nudist camp.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/edmonton/2018/07/24/in-rural-alberta-a-nudist-community-ponders-how-to-expose-younger-generations-to-the-lifestyle.html|title=In rural Alberta, a nudist community ponders how to expose younger generations to the lifestyle {{!}} The Star|work=thestar.com|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}} * Sunny Chinooks Camping Association has a landed campground for members near Sundre. They have been in operation since 1952 and also host nude swims in Calgary for members during the winter.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sunnychinooks.com/|title=Sunny Chinooks Camping Association|website=Sunny Chinooks Camping Association|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}} * Calgary Nude Recreation hosts a variety of nude and clothing-optional events for it's members. They are open to all like-minded Calgarians and do not discriminate by relationship status, gender, or sexual orientation.{{Cite web|url=https://calgarynuderecreation.ca/|title=Calgary Nude Recreation - Home|website=calgarynuderecreation.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}} ===Saskatchewan=== * Paradise Beach (Bareass Beach),{{sfn|Woycke|2006|p=187}} located just outside River access is curated by Rock River Preservation Inc.{{Cite web | title = Stewardship Agreement Signed With Property Owner | author = | work = Rock River Preservation, Inc. | date = n.d. | accessdate = 2018-06-06 | url = http://www.rockriverpreservation.org/ | language = | quote = }} * Red Rocks Park in [[South Burlington, Vermont|South Burlington]]{{cite web|url=http://www.swimmingholes.org/vt.html#BURLINGTON |title=SwimmingHole.info Burlington Area |publisher=Swimmingholes.org |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} * Starr Farm Beach in [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]][https://web.archive.org/web/20170902002023/http://www.nakedinvermont.com/library/index.php?action=artikel&cat=2&id=13&artlang=en] * Knight Island, an island in [[Lake Champlain]] just off [[St. Albans (town), Vermont|St. Albans]][https://web.archive.org/web/20180420074001/http://www.nakedinvermont.com/library/index.php?action=artikel&cat=2&id=6&artlang=en] * The Southwest Cove at [[Lake Willoughby]] in the town of [[Westmore, Vermont|Westmore]] is a traditionally clothing-optional beach area located on state land. The Westmore selectboard has declined to enact any anti-nudity ordinance. At the annual town meeting in 2009, residents voted against an appropriation that would have enabled enforcement of any proposed anti-nudity ordinance. Thus, the beach remains clothing-optional. * Maple Glen in [[Sheldon Springs, Vermont|Sheldon Springs]] closed as a family oriented nudist camp in May 2010 due to water quality issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.mapleglen.net/ |title=Maple Glen, Vermont's Best Kept Secret |publisher=Mapleglen.net |date= |accessdate=2015-08-16}} In April 2010 the camp applied for an [[Act 250 (Vermont law)|Act 250]] permit to approve already existing buildings on the property.{{cite news | title=Today In Brief | work=St. Albans Messenger (VT) | date=April 26, 2010 | location=News | pages=1A | quote=SHELDON – Maple Glen, Inc., located on Maple Glen Road in Sheldon has applied for an Act 250 permit to approve the construction of nearly a dozen already existing buildings on the property.}} In August 2014, it was revealed that it would reopen as a non-nudist campground.{{Cite news |url=http://www.samessenger.com/sheldon-partners-plan-to-dress-up-nudist-camp/ |title=SHELDON: Partners plan to dress up nudist camp |last=Reed |first=Elodie |date=August 13, 2014 |publisher=Vermont Publishing Company |newspaper=St. Albans Messenger |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203171902/http://www.samessenger.com/sheldon-partners-plan-to-dress-up-nudist-camp/ |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}} * The Punchbowl on the [[Mad River (Vermont)|Mad River]] between the intersection of [[Vermont Route 17]] in [[Warren, Vermont|Warren]] is a privately owned nude swimming hole, open to anyone. It is on the west side of [[Vermont Route 100|Route 100]], and you need to walk through a short field before encountering signs explaining that there is public nudity, and explaining the guidelines for swimming there. It's mostly just common courtesy, and there is usually a wide array of swimmers, from single men and women to entire families. There are a couple small waterfalls, a couple deep pools, and a small slide to slide down during moderate to high water periods. The water is cool, crystal clear and very refreshing. Swimmers should plan to swim nude, since visitors that swim there in a bathing suit tend to be looked at with some suspicion that they are only there to "observe" the other nude swimmers. ===Virginia=== * White Tail Resort in [[Ivor, Virginia|Ivor]]{{cite web |url=http://www.whitetailresort.org/ |title=White Tail Resort - A Virginia Family Nudist Resort since 1984 |accessdate=24 July 2012}} * [[North Anna River]] in [[Ruther Glen, Virginia|Ruther Glen]] ===Washington=== *'''Seattle''' {{Main|Social nudity in Seattle}} While [[Seattle]] is known for its [[nude cycling|nude cyclists]], clothing-optional activity in the city and out in public and out in private goes back much farther, with nude and top-free use of areas of [[Magnuson Park]], the [[Washington Park Arboretum]], [[Discovery Park (Seattle)|Discovery Park]], [[Denny-Blaine Park (Seattle)|Denny-Blaine Park]] and Secret Beach (a name given to a park that local users wish to keep a secret). Parks spokeswoman Dewey Potter said the parks department does not consider simply being naked illegal, and she doesn't remember any complaints during the 13 years she's worked for the city about nudity in the parks. While there is nothing in the Seattle Municipal Code about nudity and expectations of behavior, [[Washington (state)|Washington State]] does have a law protecting against obscene behavior while being fully or partially naked. The act of [[Breastfeeding in public|breastfeeding]] or expressing breast milk is not indecent exposure. *'''Lake Bronson Club''' is a {{convert|320|acre|adj=on}} family nudist-park nestled in the [[Cascade Range|Cascade]] foothills, {{convert|40|mi}} northeast of Seattle.{{cite web|url=http://www.lakebronson.com/about |title=About Us | Lake Bronson Club |publisher=Lakebronson.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-16}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20110523122226/http://hippieland.net/cascadia/] *'''Triangle Recreation Camp''', established in 1975, is a tent camping and RV park for gay, lesbian, and transgender people, at the foothills of the Cascades, {{convert|21|mi|abbr=on}} east of [[Granite Falls, Washington|Granite Falls]].{{cite web| url=http://www.camptrc.org/ |title=Triangle Recreation Camp |publisher=Camptrc.org |date=2011-02-21 |accessdate=2015-08-16}} ===West Virginia=== *'''Avalon Resort''' is a more than {{convert|140|acre|adj=on}} clothing-optional resort on a mountainside in the panhandle of [[West Virginia]] in [[Paw Paw, West Virginia|Paw Paw]].{{cite web|url=http://www.avalon-resort.com/ |title=Welcome to Avalon Resort |publisher=Avalon-resort.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-16}} ===Wisconsin=== * Toadally Natural Garden{{cite web|url=http://toadallynatural.com |title=Toadally Natural Garden | publisher=Toadallynatural.com|date= |accessdate=August 12, 2014}} near[[Hartford, Wisconsin|Hartford]] * [[Mazo Beach]] on the [[Wisconsin River]] was in regaular use by nudists, but it was closed to the public by the [[Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources]] in March 2016.{{Cite web | title = Homeowners say nudists at Mazomanie Beach not the problem, other illegal activity caused DNR to shut it down | last = Severson | first = Gordon | work = wkow.com | date = 8 March 2016 | accessdate = 2016-07-29 | url = http://www.wkow.com/story/31417468/2016/03/08/wisconsin-dnr-closing-mazomanie-nude-beach-effective-immediately | quote = }} * Valley View Recreation Club{{cite web|url=http://www.vvrc.org |title=Valley View Recreation Club |publisher=Vvrc.org |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} near [[Cambridge, [[Burlington, Wisconsin|Burlington]] * Aurora Gardens Nude Retreat{{cite web|url=http://www.AuroraGardens.org |title=Aurora Gardens Nude Retreat |publisher=Auroragardens.org |date= |accessdate=October We are a mixture of Nudist, Voyeurs, Exhibitionist, and Swingers, joined in one campground, to enjoy what ever your fantasies are.}}{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WISB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1194A8EE8CC7CE08&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=805787A64DB64B3893A659A756F72681 |title=ADULT-THEMED RESORT PROMOTES SPICY WEEKENDS |work=Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, WI) |date=May 20, 2007 |accessdate=December 31, 2011 |location=Local |pages=D3 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110080330/http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004 |archivedate=November 10, 2013 }} The encouragement of public sexual activity is contrary to traditional naturism. * Cedar Hills Campground, [[Mazomanie, Wisconsin|Mazomanie]] ==United States Virgin Islands== * Little Magen's Bay Beach * [[Saint John, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. John's]] Salomon Beach can be clothing optional in spite of "No Nudity" postings. === External links for USA=== *[http://www.aanr.com/ American Association for Nude Recreation] *[http://www.naturistsociety.com/ The Naturist Society] *[https://www.starkomg.com/ Stark! {{EngvarB|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} [[File:Malay world map.png|thumb|Countries in red are those most often considered to be part of the Malay world; areas where Malays are either an ethnic majority or significant minority, or where Malay language and culture have historically been influential ([[Malaysia]], [[Brunei]], [[Singapore]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Thailand]])|450px]]
The '''Malay world''' or '''Malay realm''' ([[Malay language|Malay]]: ''Dunia Melayu'' or ''Alam Melayu'', [[Jawi script|Jawi]]: دنيا ملايو or عالم ملايو) is a concept or an expression that has been utilised by different authors and groups over time to denote several different notions, derived from varied interpretations of [[Malayness]], either as a [[Malay race|racial category]], as a [[linguistic group]], or as a political-[[ethnocultural|cultural]] group. The use of the term '[[ethnic Malays|Malay]]' in much of the conceptualisation is largely based on the prevalent [[Malayisation|Malay cultural influence]], manifested in particular through [[linguistic imperialism|the spread of Malay language]] in Southeast Asia as observed by different colonial powers during the [[Age of Discovery]].<ref>{{harvnb|Ooi|2009|p=181}}</ref>
The concept in its broadest territorial stretch may apply to a region synonymous with [[Austronesia]], homeland to the [[Austronesian people]]s, that extends from [[Easter Island]] in the east to [[Madagascar]] in the west.<ref>{{harvnb|Farrer|2009|p=26}}</ref> Such description has its origin in the introduction of the term [[Malay race]] in the late 18th century that has been popularised by the [[orientalism|orientalist]]s to describe the [[Austronesian people]]s. In a narrower sense, the Malay world has been used as a [[Sprachraum]], referring to the Malay-speaking countries and territories of [[Southeast Asia]], where different standards of Malay are the [[national language]]s, or a variety of it is an important minority language. The term in this sense encompasses [[Brunei]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], and [[Southern Thailand]], and is sometimes used interchangeably with the concepts of '[[Malay Archipelago]]' and '[[Nusantara]]'.<ref>{{harvnb|Amin Sweeney|2011|p=295}}</ref>
Alternatively, modern scholars correct these extended notions of the Malay world, defining it as a political and [[cultural area]] instead. In this context, the Malay world is reduced to a region that is homeland to the [[Malay people]], historically ruled by different [[Malay sultanate]]s, where various [[Malayan languages|Malay dialects]] and cultural values are predominant. This area includes the [[Malay Peninsula]], the coastal areas of [[Sumatra]] and [[Borneo]], and the smaller islands in between.<ref>{{harvnb|Milner|1982|p=112}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Benjamin|Chou|2002|p=7}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Wee|1985|pp=61–62}}</ref>
The most notable use of the concept was in the early 20th century, embraced in an [[irredentism|irredentist]] fashion, by the [[early Malay nationalism|Malay nationalists]] in the form of '[[Greater Indonesia|Greater Malaya]]' (''Melayu Raya''), as an aspiration for the "natural" or desired borders of a modern nation for the [[Malay race]].
==Historical origin== ===Early conception=== {{Main|Malay Peninsula|Melaka Sultanate}}
{{quote box|salign=right|width=35% |quote=''"... starting point by the Island of Pulo Catay in the region of Pattane ([[Pattani]]), situated in the east coast in 8 degrees of latitude, the pass round to the other or western coast of Ujontana ([[Malay peninsula]]), to Taranda and Ujon Calan situated in the same latitude in district of Queda ([[Kedah]]): this stretch of territory lies within the region of "Malayos" and the same language prevail throughout ..."'' |source = — [[Manuel Godinho de Erédia]],1613.<ref>{{harvnb|Malaysian Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society|1923|p=37}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Mohamed Anwar Omar Din|2011|p=30}}</ref>}}
Territorial identification of Malay is of ancient origin. Various foreign and local records show that ''Melayu'' (Malay) and its similar sounding variants appear to apply as an old toponym to the ancient [[Straits of Malacca]] region in general.<ref>{{harvnb|Barnard|2004|p=3}}</ref> In the 15th century, the term gradually developed into an [[ethnonym]] throughout the consolidation of [[Melaka Sultanate]] as a regional power.<ref>{{harvnb|Barnard|2004|p=4}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Milner|2010|p=22}}</ref> [[Tome Pires]], an apothecary who stayed in Melaka from 1512 to 1515, after the [[Capture of Malacca (1511)|Portuguese conquest]], explained how the former Melaka classified merchants calling its port into four groups, of which the Malays or ''Melayu'' did not appear in the list, suggesting they were not then regarded as category outside the Melaka itself.<ref>{{harvnb|Barnard|2004|p=6}}</ref>
Another term, ''Malayos'' or the 'Sea of Malayu' was espoused by the Portuguese historian, [[Manuel Godinho de Erédia]] to describe areas under Melakan dominance.<ref>{{harvnb|Andaya|2008|p=200}}</ref> The area covers the [[Andaman Sea]] in the north, the entire [[Straits of Malacca]] in the centre, a part of [[Sunda Strait]] in the south and the western [[South China Sea]] in the east. It was generally described as a [[Muslim]] centre of international trade, with [[Malay language]] as its ''[[lingua franca]]''.<ref>{{harvnb|Mohamed Anwar Omar Din|2011|pp=28–30}}</ref> Erédia's description indicates that ''Malayos'' was a geo-religio-sociocultural concept, a concept of geographical unity characterised by the common religious belief and cultural features.<ref>{{harvnb|Mohamed Anwar Omar Din|2011|p=31}}</ref>
An identical term, ''[[Tanah Melayu]]'' (literally 'Malay land') is found in various Malay texts, of which the oldest are dating back to the early 17th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Mohamed Anwar Omar Din|2012|pp=80–81}}</ref> It is frequently mentioned in the ''[[Hikayat Hang Tuah]]'', a well known classical work that began as oral tales associated with the legendary heroes of Melaka Sultanate. ''Tanah Melayu'' in the text is consistently employed to refer to the area under Melakan dominance.<ref>{{harvnb|Reid|2010|p=95}}</ref> In the early 16th century, Tomé Pires coins an almost similar term, ''Terra de Tana Malaio'' for the southeastern part of Sumatra, where the deposed Sultan of Melaka, [[Mahmud Shah of Malacca|Mahmud Shah]] established his exiled government.
{{quote box|salign=right|align=left|width=35% |quote=''"... the country which Europeans denominate the Malay Peninsula, and which, by the natives themselves, is called 'the land of the Malays' ('Tanah Melayu'), has, from its appearing to be wholly occupied by that people, been generally considered as their original country ..."'' |source = — [[John Crawfurd]], 1820<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=211}}</ref>}}
The application of ''Tanah Melayu'' to the [[Malay Peninsula]] entered into the European authorship, when [[William Marsden (orientalist)|Marsden]] and [[John Crawfurd|Crawfurd]] noted it in their historical works published in [[1811]] and 1820 respectively. Another important term, the ''Malaya'', an English term for the Peninsula, was already used in English writings from the early 18th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=211}}</ref>
Due to the lack of available research, it is difficult to trace the development of the concept of the Malay world as a term which later refers to the Archipelago. However, above early territorial identifications are believed to have formed an important antecedent for the future conceptualisation of the Malay world.<ref>{{harvnb|Andaya|2008|p=46}}</ref>
===Malay as a racial category=== {{main|Malay race}} The broader concept of Malay world has its origin from the conceptualisation of Malay as a race by the German scientist [[Johann Friedrich Blumenbach]]. Blumenbach identified 'Malay' as a subcategory of both the [[Ethiopid race|Ethiopid]] and [[Mongoloid]] races, and expanded the term to include the native inhabitants of the [[Mariana Islands|Marianas]], the [[Philippines]], the [[Maluku Islands|Malukus]], [[Sunda Islands|Sundas]], [[Indochina]], as well as [[Pacific Island]]s like the [[Tahiti]]ans. This broad conception of Malay was largely derived from the strong presence of [[Malayisation|Malay cultural influence]], particularly in linguistic, throughout the [[Southeast Asia]] at the time of European colonisation.<ref>{{harvnb|Ooi|2009|p=181}}</ref> Malay language was one aspect of the prestige of the Malay sultanates, and considered as a language of the learned in Southeast Asia in the 17th and 18th century comments. An 18th century European account even suggests that one is not considered a very broadly educated man in the east, if he don't understand Malay.<ref>{{harvnb|Milner|2010|p=81}}</ref>
The popularisation of Malay as a racial category was in essence a colonial product, the significant role of which played by the [[Spanish Empire|Spanish]] since the 17th century and that of the [[British Empire|British]] since the 18th century in identifying [[Maritime Southeast Asia|the Archipelago]] as the Malay world. The view held by [[Thomas Stamford Raffles]] for example, had a significant influence on English-speakers, lasting to the present day. He should probably be regarded as the most important voice in projecting the idea of a 'Malay' race or nation, not limited to the traditional [[Malay rulers|Raja-Raja Melayu]] or even their supporters, but embracing a large if unspecified part of the Archipelago.<ref>{{harvnb|Reid|2001|pp=296–313}}</ref> [[William Marsden (orientalist)|William Marsden]], another British "merchant-scientist," classified the inhabitants of the Archipelago as Malays, based on religion ([[Islam]]), language ([[Malay language|Malay]]) and origin.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=212}}</ref>
===Malay territoriality in three tiers=== In the late 19th century, an important innovation was introduced into the political vocabulary of the [[Malay language]]. The word ''kerajaan'', which had in older times usually meant "king," "royalty" and "kingdom," began to be defined as "government". In the same period, the term ''negeri'' was increasingly being used as a word equivalent to "state," in contrast to its earlier use in court texts more in the sense of a 'settlement' than of a political entity. With growing frequency, publications of the 1870s and 1880s employed the term to refer either to individual [[Malay sultanate]]s or any political state in the world beyond the Malay territories.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=211}}</ref>
British historian, [[Richard James Wilkinson|Wilkinson]], prefers the term "state" to refer to an administrative or territorial unit in the Malay Peninsula in his time, while he uses the word "kingdom" or "sultanate" for a Malay polity of older times. While Wilkinson often uses "the Peninsula" or "the Malay Peninsula," he also calls the Peninsula "[[British Malaya|Malaya]]." His use of the word "Malaya" occasionally includes not merely the Peninsula under British rule but also its other parts under [[Rattanakosin Kingdom|Siamese rule]]. In referring to [[Maritime Southeast Asia|the Archipelago]], Wilkinson not only uses "the Archipelago" or "the Indian Archipelago," but also "the Malay world," which might have more sociocultural connotations.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=212}}</ref>
Among the textbooks available during [[British Malaya|colonial Malaya]], [[Richard Olaf Winstedt|Winstedt]]'s ''Ilmu Alam Melayu'' ('Geography of the Malay world') presents the clearest picture of the territoriality of the Malay community. As expressed in the title, Winstedt attempts to cover most of the Archipelago. He describes not only the British colonies and protectorates in the Malay Peninsula and Borneo, but also the [[Netherlands East Indies]] and the [[Philippines]]. The structure of ''Ilmu Alam Melayu'' shows the three-tiered constitution of the Malay world. The Malay world (''Alam Melayu'') is divided into sub-regions, namely, Malaya (''Tanah Melayu''), the [[British Borneo|British Borneo territories]], the Netherlands East Indies and the Philippines. Malaya, in turn, is made up of the [[Malay states]] (''Negeri-Negeri Melayu''). It is also important to note the standardization of geographical knowledge in this geography textbook. All states in the Peninsula, the main islands and areas of the Netherlands East Indies and all of the Philippines are systematically discussed through the common topics of overview, districts and towns, products, inhabitants and history. Such a systematic and comprehensive catalogue of geographical knowledge helps to convey an image of the Malay world as a territorial entity.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|pp=213–214}}</ref>
Malay historian Abdul Hadi Haji Hassan, who cites Winstedt's textbooks in his ''Sejarah 'Alam Melayu'' ('History of the Malay world'), had much in common with Winstedt's view of the Malay world. For Abdul Hadi, too, the Malay territories are made up of the Malay states, Malaya and the Malay world. Of the 12 chapters in the three volumes of Abdul Hadi's textbook, four chapters focus on the history of the [[Ethnic Malays|Malays]] in Malaya, while other chapters deal with the history of the Malays in both Malaya and other parts of the Malay world. It ought to be added that the history of each colony or state (''negeri'') in the [[Straits Settlements]] and the [[Federated Malay States]] is explained in the fourth and the fifth volumes of the book written by another Malay historian, [[Buyong Adil]] in 1934 and 1940. Thus, both British and Malay authors conceptualised Malay territoriality in three tiers, that is, the [[Malay states]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]] and the Malay world.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=214}}</ref>
===Malay nationalism=== {{main|Malay nationalism}} The standardisation of geographical knowledge and systematic quantification, served to objectify the territoriality of the Malay community. Early authors in Malaya also developed a Malaya-centric view on the subject, proclaiming Malaya or ''Tanah Melayu'' as the focal point of the Malay territories. This view reflected the substantialisation of the colonial territorial boundary and provided new objectification of space seems to have played an important role in conceiving a potential national territory. It is probable that these three territorial identities, namely, Malay states, Malaya and the Malay world had much to do with the strands of [[Malay nationalism]].<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=229}}</ref>
On the one hand, in the late 1930s, Malay aristocrats and their supporters began to organize Malay state associations. For them, Malay states were the focus of territorial identity. In postwar Malaya, these state-based Malay associations were dissolved into a Malaya-based Malay political party, that is, the [[United Malays National Organisation]]. Their territorial identity was gradually shifted from Malay states to Malaya or ''[[Persekutuan Tanah Melayu|Tanah Melayu]]''. On the other hand, in the late 1930s, some Malay non-aristocrat intellectuals formed a pan-Malay-oriented association, that is, [[Kesatuan Melayu Muda]] or Young Malay Union. As shown by its President, [[Ibrahim Hj Yaacob]], the territorial stretch of their imagined homeland covered the Malay world or the [[Malay Archipelago]] as a whole.<ref>{{harvnb|Soda|2001|p=229}}</ref>
==Modern conception== Although the extended notions of Malay world still gained widespread currency, particularly in Malaysia, Singapore and the English-speaking world, such conceptualisation is sometimes described in other terms, perceived as more 'neutral', like [[Nusantara]], [[Indonesian archipelago]], and [[Maritime Southeast Asia]]. New approaches have also been taken by modern authors to redefine the 'Malay world', by taking into account the historic political pattern of the region, in addition to the existing racial-linguistic spread model.
In this context, modern authors in Malay studies like [[Anthony Milner (historian)|Anthony Milner]], Geoffrey Benjamin, and Vivienne Wee provide a narrower definition, reducing the concept into a political and [[cultural area]]. Benjamin for example, describes the concept in an historically responsive manner to refer to the areas currently or formerly falling under ''Kerajaan Melayu'' ('Malay kingdoms'), the rule of a Malay king. It does not refer to [[Insular Southeast Asia]] at large, and certainly not the [[Austronesian people|Austronesian]]-speaking world as a whole, both of which are usages of Malay world that have crept into scholarly discourse. In this sense, the Malay world refers to various kingdoms and their attendant hinterlands that have existed or still exist along the coasts of [[Brunei]], the east coast of [[Sumatra]] and on the [[Malay peninsula]].<ref>{{harvnb|Benjamin|Chou|2002|p=7}}</ref>
This limited conceptualisation of Malay world was also espoused by Wee. She added further, that the concept is a spatial configuration that resulted from the serial patterning of political alliances, unified by ''[[Sejarah Melayu]]'', that is a particular genealogical tree of kingship. The other, non-Malay areas would be those where the rulers did not claim to belong to this particular genealogical tree. For example, [[Aceh]] is located on the northern tip of the Sumatran mainland, yet the rulers evidently did not claim to belong to the Malay genealogical tree. And indeed Aceh is generally not regarded as part of ''Alam Melayu''. On the contrary, both the indigenous and foreign texts indicate that Aceh, similar to [[Java]], was an historical enemy of ''Alam Melayu''. Hence to locate oneself within ''Alam Melayu'' is to claim membership in a specific network of political alliances.<ref>{{harvnb|Wee|1985|pp=63–65}}</ref>

[[File:Quebec province topographic map-fr.svg|thumb|Quebec province topographic map with census cities]] '''Metageography''' is a term used by [[Martin W. Lewis]] and [[Kären E. Wigen]]'s 1997 ''The Myth of Continents: A Critique of Metageography'',<ref>{{cite book |last=Lewis |first=Martin W. |authorlink= |author2=Kären E. Wigen |title=The Myth of Continents: a Critique of Metageography |year=1997 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley |ISBN=0-520-20742-4 |pages=35 |chapter= |quote= }} (hardcover; {{ISBN|0-520-20743-2}} paperback)</ref> which analyzes metageographical constructs such as "East", "West", "Europe", "Asia", "North" or "South". which they define as "the set of spatial structures through which people order their knowledge of the world" Geographies, wrote one reviewer, are thus much more than just the ways in which societies are stretched across the earth's surface. They also include the "contested, arbitrary, power-laden, and often inconsistent ways in which those structures are represented epistemologically."<ref>[http://www.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v1/4/7.htm Book review by Barney Warf, African Studies Center]</ref>
In an interview, Martin explained: "By 'metageography' I mean the relatively unexamined and often taken-for-granted spatial frameworks through which knowledge is organized within all fields of the social sciences and humanities." He added that "the distinction between the merely geographical and the metageographical is not always clear-cut.<ref>Leonhardt van Efferink [http://www.exploringgeopolitics.org/interview_lewis_martin_metageographies_postmodernism_fallacy_of_unit_comparability_historical_spatial_ideological_development_constructs_taxonomy_ideas_systems/ Martin Lewis: Metageographies, postmodernism and fallacy of unit comparability] ''Exploring Geopolitics'' August 2010 (Accessed 05/01/2015)</ref>
The term was criticized by [[James M. Blaut]]: "the word metageography seems to have been coined by the authors as an impressive-sounding synonym for 'world cultural geography.'"<ref>{{cite journal |last =Blaut |first =James M |authorlink = |title =The Myth of Continents: A Critique of Metageography (Review) |journal =Journal of World History |volume =10 |issue = 1 |pages =205–210 |publisher = |location = |date =1999 |language = |url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/jwh/summary/v010/10.1blaut.html |jstor = |issn = |doi = 10.1353/jwh.2005.0002 |accessdate = |ref= none}}</ref> Lewis and Wigen, however, disagreed.<ref>{{cite journal |last =Lewis, Martin W and Karen Wigen |first = |authorlink = |title =Third Worldism or Globalism? Reply to James M. Blaut's Review of the Myth of Continents |journal =Journal of World History |volume =11 |issue = 1 |pages =81–92 |publisher = |location = |date =2000 |language = |url = |jstor = |issn = |doi = 10.1353/jwh.2000.0017 |accessdate = |ref= none}}</ref>
In 1969, Soviet geographers Gokhman, Gurevich and Saushkin wrote that "[m]etageography is concerned with study of the common basis of geographical regularities and the potentialities of geography as a science" and argued that many factors must be taken into account in order to define geographical entities, not simply spatial ones.<ref>
{{cite journal | authors =Gokhman, V. M., B. L. Gurevich and Yu G. Saushkin |first = |authorlink = |title =Problems of Metageography |journal =Soviet Geography |volume =10 |issue = 7 |pages =355–364 |publisher = |location = |date =1969 |language = |url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00385417.1969.10770421 |jstor = |issn = |doi = 10.1080/00385417.1969.10770421 |accessdate = |ref= none}}</ref>
